Please arrive in Ushuaia the day before Day 1 to allow for smooth embarkation. At Swoop, we would be delighted to assist with any hotel and excursion bookings in Ushuaia.
column46: During these days at sea, your vessel will cross the Antarctic Convergence, where the temperature dips within just a few hours. Colliding columns of water push nutrients to the surface, attracting many species of seabirds - from albatrosses and shearwaters to petrels, prions and skuas. This will give you a small taste of what is to come on South Georgia, a remote island known as the “Serengeti of the South” because of its sheer concentration of incredible wildlife.
column60: As you enter one of Earth's largest swathes of protected waters, you'll pass Shag Rocks, which thousands of South Georgia shags call home. Look out for larger marine mammals such as humpback whales here too, drawn to the rich feeding grounds of the shallow South Georgia Ridge. Next on the agenda are some of South Georgia's iconic sites, which could include Fortuna Bay. This scenic plain, washed out by the Fortuna Glacier, teems with king penguins and seals. Here, if conditions allow, you might have the opportunity to trace the finale of legendary polar explorer Ernest Shackleton's route to the abandoned whaling village of Stromness. As this path slices across the mountain pass beyond Shackleton's Waterfall, and has swampy terrain, be prepared to walk through a handful of small streams.Other potential stop-off points on South Georgia include Salisbury Plain, St Andrews Bay and Gold Harbour. These sites are home to the three biggest king penguin colonies on the island and also lay claim to the world's largest breeding beaches for Antarctic fur seals. Millions breed here in high season, and by the time February rolls around, adorable young fur seals splash through the surf while huge elephant seals haul out to moult. At the rusting remnants of Grytviken, one of the island's best-preserved whaling stations, you may stop to peruse the thought-provoking maritime exhibition in the South Georgia Museum. You may also head to the nearby cemetery to visit Shackleton's grave, to pay a whisky tributes to ‘The Boss,' as he was affectionately called by his crew. As Day 6 ends, weather permitting, your ship will begin to sail towards the South Sandwich Islands.Please note that the ship's helicopters aren't allowed to fly in or around South Georgia.
column69: Just like Shackleton in December 1914 on his notorious Endurance Expedition, you'll depart South Georgia and set off towards the Weddell Sea.Potential sea ice encounters mean that these waters can be challenging to navigate. Yet the journey will be far from lonely. Keep your eyes peeled for south polar skuas and snow petrels joining the flock of seabirds trailing the ship as you venture further south.
column77: While you can't leave the ship and explore on shore here, a zodiac cruise amid the mesmerising landscape will be planned.There will be a high chance of encountering humpback and minke whales in these rich feeding grounds. As you watch out for marine mammals, let yourself be distracted now and again by brown skuas and grey-headed, black-browed or even wandering albatrosses soaring through the skies. You might also spot chinstrap or Adelie penguins as you near land.
column85: During these few days, your ship will sail toward the extremely remote Queen Maud Land and Neuschwabenland (New Swabia) on the Antarctic continent, the northeast side of the Weddell Sea. Make the most of the vessel's program of educational lectures led by the Antarctic experts in the expedition team and spend time out on deck looking for wildlife as you sail.
column93: New Swabia will be your first planned destination in Antarctica, an area explored by Germany's Third Reich on the cusp of the Second World War. While attempting to claim the region during this dark time in history, foot soldiers placed Nazi flags on the sea ice while survey flights airdropped swastika-covered aluminium arrows. This area of Antarctica is extremely remote and very rarely visited by expedition ships.
column103: As you head into the beautiful landscapes of the Antarctic Sound, you might stop off at one of the most scenic destinations on this side of the Antarctic Continent. An enormous Adelie penguin colony, along with gentoo penguins and nesting snow petrels, are also to be found in this area. Photographers will delight in the challenge of capturing Brown Bluff's impossibly steep canyon walls, haphazard boulders and ice-capped scenery. Kinnes Cove, where you can admire the light-red shades of the Madder Cliffs, also sits just across the Antarctic Sound.
column111: History buffs will be pleased to approach the point where Shackleton left to seek rescue for his 22 men, stranded after his Endurance ship sank in the Weddell Sea. In a tiny lifeboat, he and five others set sail for South Georgia and then hiked for 36 hours to the busy whaling station at Stromness. From start to end, it took 4.5 months to complete this legendary rescue.It's extremely difficult to safely land on Elephant Island as the coastline consists of vertical rock and highly exposed ice cliffs, making the Endurance crew's survival even more impressive. However, if conditions allow it, you'll take a zodiac to view Point Wild, where the deserted members of Shackleton's expedition waited for rescue.
column119: While crossing the Drake Passage, you might spot some of the same wildlife seen at the beginning of your trip: albatrosses, petrels and perhaps even the distant blows of passing whales. This is the perfect time to reflect on your adventures and sort through photos, as well as continuing the educational program laid on by your expedition team.
column127: On this final day, your epic voyage comes to a close. After breakfast, it's time to disembark in Ushuaia and continue your journey, whether you're extending your time in the region or heading home.

column5: Experience Antarctica from a hybrid diesel-electric ship with reduced fuel consumption, lower CO2 emissions and quieter sailing. Off-ship exploration, including optional kayaking and camping, is complemented by educational lectures, citizen science workshops, and crafts sessions. Relax in outdoor jacuzzis while soaking up dramatic polar landscapes.
column37: The perfect beginning to an Antarctic voyage, your trip includes a complimentary night's stay in Buenos Aires.  This city combines grand European-style architecture with a lively South American spirit. Try a sumptuous Argentine steak in a local parilla or immerse yourself in a tango show.
column46: It's an early morning start today for your charter flight south to Ushuaia, the city at the bottom of South America. A transfer will take you and your fellow travellers from the airport to the port, where your hybrid-powered expedition ship awaits. Purpose built for sailing in challenging polar seas, this vessel feels right at home in this gateway to Antarctica. The world's southernmost city is set in a stunning location, ringed by snow-dusted mountains.  Enjoy the setting and look out for wildlife from the ship's spacious decks as you set sail down the Beagle Channel.
column60: On your two days of sailing across the Drake Passage, your expedition team's friendly and knowledgeable guides will inform and excite you ahead of your arrival in Antarctica. Join lectures to learn about everything from iconic wildlife such as penguins and albatross, to polar history and even glaciology. Spend time exploring the ship's facilities; the unique onboard science centre is fully equipped to help you build on your Antarctic knowledge in your own time. Biosecurity sessions are also planned during these days at sea to help you understand how to travel safely and with as little impact on the delicate Antarctic environment as possible. Relaxation time will also be on the agenda to prepare you for the adventures ahead. Enjoy soothing sessions in the sumptuous spa, dine on delectable meals in the multiple restaurants, and mingle with other guests in the spacious Explorer Lounge & Bar.
column69: During these five days in Antarctica, you'll be awestruck by the otherworldly spectacle of glaciers and icebergs. As you gaze across the landscape, take note of the silence too; its profoundness is only interrupted by the extraordinary wildlife that calls this region home. Watch as penguins porpoise through the water and seals lounge on ice floes while you keep an eye out for whales gorging on krill.  Nature reigns supreme here, so your Captain will adapt the itinerary according to the ever-changing weather and ice conditions. Each day will bring excitement, whether you're out on landings and zodiac cruises or have chosen to book an optional kayak trip to paddle among bobbing bergs. With up to 500 guests on board and in compliance with landing restrictions in Antarctica, should conditions allow, the expedition team will be aiming to offer one landing excursion and one zodiac cruise per guest per day. These will each last approximately 45-60 minutes. When you're on board, yet more educational and immersive lectures will be planned by your expedition team, deepening your appreciation for Antarctica. The Science Center will play host to dedicated workshops to take a microscopic look at samples collected by those who have participated in the Citizen Science zodiac trips. Enjoy your downtime with a visit to the bubbling outdoor hot tubs - the perfect spot from which to enjoy the glorious Antarctic landscapes.
column77: After these five amazing days, your mind is bound to swirl with unforgettable memories. Spend your homeward journey on the Drake Passage sorting through the thousands of snapshots on your camera or reminiscing with fellow travellers about your trip. As well as continuing the educational program, there will also be opportunities to capture your Antarctic experience in a more creative way, with craft workshops where you might paint a postcard or craft a clay penguin.
column85: Your cruise will finish in Ushuaia, where it began. From here you'll hop aboard a charter flight back to Buenos Aires and continue your journey onward, whether elsewhere in the region or home.

column5: Spend an incredible 9 whole days exploring the Antarctic Peninsula and deep inside the Antarctic Circle on one of the polar fleet's most high tech ships. Benefiting from over 50 years of Antarctic operational experience, and in the company of a National Geographic photography expert, you’ll venture past 66°33 south. Complimentary kayaking session included.
column37: After touching down in Argentina's cosmopolitan capital, you'll have the rest of the day to explore as you please. Savour the city's renowned steaks at a local restaurant or experience the lively rhythms of a tango show. Your high-class hotel this evening is included as part of your cruise package.
column45: Fly to Ushuaia, Argentina, and embark on your ship
column46: An early start this morning for your charter flight to the world's most southerly city, nestled within Argentine Patagonia. On arrival you'll head for lunch on a scenic catamaran cruise, as you sail on the Beagle Channel look out for sea lions, petrels and perhaps even your first albatross. Returning to Ushuaia port you will embark on your purpose-built expedition vessel and settle into your cabin, ready for the adventure ahead.
column60: This 600-mile-long strait between South America and the Antarctic Peninsula is among the most renowned bodies of water in the world. Notorious for its unpredictable nature, the Drake Passage can be fiercely turbulent or perfectly calm. As you traverse this captivating stretch of sea, head out on deck to spot stunning seabirds such as the wandering albatross and giant petrels with their astounding wingspans. These sea days also offer the opportunity to get familiar with your ship and ready for the excitement ahead. You can visit the Bridge, a prime spot for wildlife viewing, enjoy a soothing massage or attend an informative talk on the penguins you'll soon encounter. Lectures will be held throughout these days at sea to bring you up to speed on Antarctica's fascinating history, wildlife and geology, among other immersive topics.You could also relax in the observation lounge, gazing over the waves and contemplating the rich history of this legendary passage. If the conditions on the Drake pick up, a couple of restful naps will help pass the time, and before you know it, you'll finally be in Antarctica.
column68: Exploring en route to the Antarctic Circle
column69: Daylight hours are long at this time of year, so your ship's Captain and Expedition Leader should be able to maximise your time. Nine full days on the White Continent also give you ample opportunities to explore. In fact, there will be plenty of chances to immerse yourself in the spirit of history's most daring explorers as your ship moves south, aiming to cross the legendary Antarctic Circle. The flexible schedule and state-of-the-art ship allow you to venture deeper and explore further, embracing the unexpected - whether it's watching whales surface alongside the ship, walking among thousands of Adélie and gentoo penguins, taking an evening zodiac cruise under the stunning midnight sun, or discovering an uncharted cove. Yet while the wildlife and landscapes are breathtaking, it's the ice that truly defines Antarctica. You'll get an up-close and personal encounter with it, from island-sized bergs to towering glaciers interspersed by the delicate, nearly invisible layers just beginning to freeze. One day, you'll perhaps kayak alongside statuesque ice arches or zodiac cruise in search of seals and blue-eyed shags. The next, you could feel the thrill of the ship crunching through the pack ice. Everywhere you go, Antarctica will offer countless photogenic moments, and you'll be able to enjoy expert guidance on improving your skills from the onboard National Geographic photography expert. During the journey, the professionals in the expedition team will also continue to enrich your experience with plenty of lectures and opportunities for learning while your skilled Captain safely weaves through the near-frozen waters.
column76: At sea on the Drake Passage
column77: Wave farewell to Antarctica and the ship will begin to navigate back to the southernmost tip of South America. En route, you'll pass where the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans meet. During these two days at sea, spend some time sifting through your photographs and revelling in the memories you made. The educational program will also continue to enthral guests hungry for further knowledge of this spectacular region. A final celebratory dinner allows you to say goodbye properly to newfound friends.
column84: Disembark in Ushuaia and return to Buenos Aires
column85: Today, you will disembark the ship in Ushuaia before taking your included charter flight from this Argentinean port city back to Buenos Aires. From here continue your journey onwards, either on further travels or home.

column5: Encounter a diverse blend of history, landscapes and epic wildlife with an impressive 12 days of off-ship exploring the Falklands, South Georgia and Antarctica. A pre-voyage Santiago hotel stay and domestic charter flights are included for maximum convenience and value. Renovated in 2022, your purpose-built expedition ship hosts just 200 guests in comfortable Nordic style.
column37: Your trip begins in Santiago where you will make your way into the city centre for  your complimentary night's stay with breakfast included. Take the opportunity to explore Chile's energetic capital city after check-in. From the booming food scene to the immersive museums, there's plenty to keep you busy. For breathtaking views, travel up to the heady heights of the Sky Costanera skyscraper. Alternatively, browse the colourful produce in Mercado Central and learn about Chile's tumultuous history at the Presidential Palace.
column46: It's an early morning today as you transfer to board your included charter flight from Santiago to Punta Arenas. After another group transfer from the airport, your expedition ship will await your arrival in one of Chile's southernmost ports. Once you board and settle in, it's time to get to know the vessel's facilities and your expedition team. These approachable and knowledgeable guides will be on hand to answer all your queries about the three diverse destinations you're about to visit.
column59: En Route to the Falkland Islands
column60: As you sail towards the Falkland Islands, enjoy spectacular views of the Strait of Magellan. from the ship's spacious deck - or even the outdoor hot tub. The Explorer Lounge & Bar, with its panoramic windows, is yet another cosy space for surveying the vast ocean in comfort. While you settle in on your first full day at sea, your expedition team will host lectures and Citizen Science sessions in the well-equipped Science Center and lecture room. Specialists in everything from marine biology to photography, they are fully prepared to offer in-depth information on your adventures ahead. There may be an educational session planned on the Yaghan people, the original inhabitants of South America's most southerly channels and islands, with the onboard anthropologist, during your days at sea.
column69: The Falkland Islands are an often-overlooked gem blessed with a seemingly endless expanse of white sand beaches brimming with birdlife. Grass-covered hills and wildflowers offer a striking juxtaposition against the icy vastness of Antarctica that lies ahead, with only the odd isolated farm punctuating the scenery here and there. The ship will also offer additional tour options in Stanley, which can be booked at extra cost.  Please see below for more information. The staff at the Expedition Desk on your ship can also provide further details on the options.A guided community walk through the Falkands' capital is included, with stops at highlights such as the well-kept Jubilee Villa Gardens and 19th-century Christchurch Cathedral. Throughout the expedition, your itinerary will be tailored to the daily weather conditions to maximise the best off-ship opportunities for you to explore.
column77: Departing from the Falkland Islands, your ship will cruise towards the wildlife haven of South Georgia. During the journey, your expedition team will provide a crash course in what to expect from this jaw-dropping island, from its rich history to its distinctive geology. Biosecurity briefings will be held to ensure your exploration has as little effect on the delicate ecosystem as possible with time dedicated to scrubbing your kit ready for inspection by South Georgia's diligent wildlife wardens. You can also take part in the Citizen Science programme to assist in collecting data for worldwide research projects.
column85: Spend four incredible traversing this extraordinary region. As you catch your first glimpse of South Georgia's abundant wildlife, you'll immediately understand why this island is often referred to as the ‘Serengeti of the Southern Ocean.'Due to its one-of-a-kind location away from sea ice, South Georgia has become a breeding ground for large rookeries of penguins, as well as colonies of seabirds and seals. It's designated an “Important Bird Area” as it's the habitat of numerous species, including albatrosses, petrels, shags, skuas and terns.  A visit to Grytviken, the last resting place of legendary polar explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton and an extraordinary remnant of the haunting whaling industry, is also on the agenda. Nature always guides the journey in these parts, and as usual, the itinerary will need to flex depending on the conditions to ensure you receive the best possible experience. Ensuring you maintain a safe distance to the wildlife is a must, and with beaches often heavily crowded with thousands of penguins and seals, your expedition team may sometimes opt for a water-based zodiac safari. Whether you're landing on the island or cruising its waters, it's all part of the adventure.
column93: After your adventures in the Falklands and South Georgia, enjoy a well-deserved break on the ship as you sail towards Antarctica. As you near the continent, the expedition team will educate you on the IAATO environmental guidelines and sustainability rules to follow while visiting. As in the Falklands and South Georgia, the aim is to leave nothing but footprints and take nothing but pictures.  Head out on deck to look for the blow of passing whales and massive icebergs.
column103: Antarctica's vast, icy grandeur gives South Georgia a run for its money in the scenic stakes. Prepare to be awed by sculptural icebergs floating in the straits, comical penguins flitting around on shore, and graceful seabirds soaring overhead. Nature reigns supreme in this iconic part of the world, and you'll be given four whole days to explore it. Many potential landing sites are scattered across the Antarctic Peninsula and South Shetland Islands. Your Captain and Expedition Leader will adapt the itinerary based on the weather and ice conditions, so each day will be a fantastic surprise. Days might include sailing into a flooded volcanic crater and exploring partly frozen bays where vestiges of the now-defunct whaling industry lie. You will visit bustling penguin rookeries, watching these petite birds waddle to and from their rock nests. The fleet of study zodiacs will take you on magical sea safaris through glorious iceberg graveyards, on the look out for whales and seals. Birders may struggle to tear their eyes away from skies brimming with skuas, petrels and terns. Your guides will also educate you about these creatures, as well as much more, during the continuing programme of lectures and talks.
column111: As you bid Antarctica farewell, your ship will turn north and sail across the Drake Passage towards Punta Arenas. These two days at sea bridge the gap between your trip and homecoming to civilization. It's the ideal stretch of time to peruse your photographs and file through your new memories. The educational programming will also continue so there's plenty more to learn before you disembark! Just before landing back in South America, the vessel will enter the scenic Beagle Channel, encircled by mountains tumbling down into the chilly waters. Keep an eye out for native Patagonian species as you sail through this remote part of the world.
column119: Your epic adventure ends in Punta Arenas. From here, you will be transferred to the airport for your charter flight back to Santiago, from where you can continue your onward travels.

column3: Falklands, South Georgia & Antarctica in Focus
column5: A chic Scandi-style vessel with an informal onboard atmosphere is your launchpad for this wildlife-rich expedition covering the dramatic trifecta of the Falklands, South Georgia and Antarctica. Smooth domestic travel logistics in Argentina are woven into the inclusive itinerary for a relaxed, hassle-free experience from start to finish.
column37: The date of Day 1 for each voyage reflects the date that you will embark on your ship. However, the price of your trip also includes additional services pre-voyage to ensure a hassle-free experience on arrival into Argentina. Once you have landed in Buenos Aires (on the day before your embarkation date) you will be met and transferred to your included 4-5* city centre hotel, where you will spend the night.Please see the final paragraph of this itinerary for the included arrangements once you have disembarked.
column46: After an early breakfast, you will be transferred to the airport in Buenos Aires for your included charter flight to Ushuaia at the southern tip of Argentina. Flanking the foothills of the snow-covered Martial Range, this port destination's eclectic architecture tumbles down to the edges of the Beagle Channel. Known as the world's most southerly city, it serves as a scenic start to your trip. Upon arrival in Ushuaia, embark on your beautifully designed ship and begin journeying towards one of the most spectacular regions on the planet.
column60: As you sail towards your first destination - the Falkland Islands - relax and familiarise yourself with your home for this epic expedition. The spacious observation decks on your vessel will afford you with sweeping vistas of the passing sea. You will also have the chance to meet other guests, peruse the Antarctic reference books in the ship's polar library and get to know your onboard guides.Engaging lectures are planned by the highly knowledgeable expedition team, who will share their expertise on the flora and fauna you will encounter along the way. Professional photographers are also on hand to offer tips on capturing the stunning scenery ahead.
column68: West Point Island and Saunders Island, Falklands Islands
column69: Spectacular birdlife is the main lure on these two verdant sheep-grazed islands, where rams and ewes roam and intermingle with more exotic wildlife. Established by British explorers in 1765, the Falklands brims with distinctive landscapes, including a coastline littered by rockhopper, gentoo and even small king penguin rookeries. Keep an eye out for the pillar-shaped nests of black browed albatrosses too, as well as nine of the archipelago's 14 endemic plants, such as silvery buttercup and hairy daisy. These remote islands have such a minuscule human population - penguins outnumber people here! The Falklands are also a haven for fur seals, Commerson's dolphins and imperial cormorants. Spot the latter nesting along the cliffs as you trek past mossy landscapes revealing vibrant wildflowers, such as the pink-petalled Felton's.
column77: Port Stanley, the quaint capital of the Falkland Islands on East Falkland, is compact enough to explore by foot. If you are acquainted with the United Kingdom, you might recognise the classic red post boxes in this British outpost. The quirky Historic Dockyard Museum provides a fascinating glimpse into maritime history and exploration. If you visit nearby Gypsy Cove dolphins cruising through the turquoise waters, while yellow gorse offsets the white sand of the beach below.
column85: Days at sea are the ideal opportunity to rest and indulge in the ship's facilities - from the well-equipped gym to the serene spa. Alternatively, spend time out on deck bird and whale spotting or curl up with a novel in your spacious cabin. These sea days are a relaxing counterbalance to busy periods spent navigating on land. However, there's still plenty to do as the educational program of lectures will continue, preparing you for arrival at jaw-dropping South Georgia.
column93: Often referred to as the 'Galapagos of the Southern Ocean', South Georgia is a wildlife paradise. It boasts several landing sites home to up to 500,000 king penguins and three million breeding pairs of macaroni penguins. The region is also renowned for its enormous elephant seal colonies, where the huge creatures can often be seen lounging in the surf and maintaining their territories. Feisty fur seals also litter the beaches, with opportunistic scavenger birds such as snowy sheathbills and skuas adding to the melee. History is also part and parcel of a trip to South Georgia, though it can sometimes be quite haunting as you learn of the damage wrought by decades of sealing and whaling.  One of the island's most notable sites is Grytviken, the iconic whaling station where legendary British explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton is laid to rest.Your time exploring South Georgia will be heavily dictated by the weather conditions influencing this notoriously windy island. Wildlife can also cause plans to change, as sometimes the beaches are so heavily laden with seals and penguins that it's impossible to land! Your expedition team will make the most of the opportunities to get you off the ship and you may enjoy shoreline safaris by zodiac, which gives you a great water-level angle for your wildlife photography.
column102: At sea towards the Antarctic Peninsula
column103: As you head south towards Antarctica your days at sea will be filled with engaging educational briefings and presentations covering topics such as Antarctic wildlife, history and geology. There will also be opportunities to venture out on deck to witness the majestic albatrosses and giant petrels soaring by. You may be able to participate in citizen science activities, including bird species counts and cloud surveys for a NASA observation project.
column111: With its heavily crevassed and seemingly endless glaciers, towering icebergs and snow-laden islands, the Antarctic Peninsula offers the iconic polar experience. This accessible region lays claim to active scientific research bases and awe-inspiring landscapes. As you head on shore, the penguins you encounter will be more petite than the kings you've met in South Georgia, but arguably more comical with their energetic waddling to and from their rookeries. Zodiac cruises will have you gliding amongst the sculptural icebergs, on the lookout for whales and seals.
column119: These last days at sea can be spent immersing yourself in the facilities of your chic ship. Attend a lecture from the onboard experts or simply soak up the ocean views from the deck accompanied by more gliding seabirds. It's also a great time to reflect on your adventure and start to sort through your hundreds of photos!
column127: Today, you will end your journey back in the port city at the southernmost tip of South America, where your Antarctic cruise began. Here, you will be taken to the airport for your charter flight back up to Buenos Aires, and from there, you can make arrangements for onward travel home.

column5: Helicopters give a jaw-dropping bird's eye view of the White Continent aboard this unique voyage to the Antarctic Peninsula's little-explored northeastern tip. Your outstanding purpose-built vessel has a highly experienced expedition team and two top-of-the range helicopters. Included charter flights from Buenos Aires to Ushuaia make for a hassle free adventure.
column37: Arrive in the cosmopolitan, colourful capital of Argentina and make your own way to your hotel where a pre-voyage night is included as part of your trip. Settle in, then soak up the European roots and architecture of this grand destination before tomorrow's flight to the country's southernmost tip.
column45: Fly to Ushuaia and embark on your ship
column46: Fuel up with an early breakfast at the hotel before taking a group transfer to the airport for your included charter flight to Ushuaia. Upon arrival, you'll be whisked to the heart of this port city at the southernmost part of South America, leaving you with a few hours to explore.In the late afternoon, you'll board the ship and begin your cruise along the emblematic Beagle Channel. This scenic waterway cuts through the Tierra del Fuego archipelago for a picture-perfect start to your journey. As you peel away from South America, the next time you spot land you will be in the wilds of Antarctica!
column60: Sailing across this renowned 500-mile (800km) waterway is a bucket-list experience for many travellers. From the deck of the ship, take in the mesmerising seascapes as they extend towards the distant horizon. Watch out for a variety of seabirds, including albatrosses, petrels and skuas as they gracefully soar over the powerful waves. As you near the Antarctic Peninsula, stay alert for your first sight of towering icebergs, carved into mind-boggling shapes by the power of the polar winds. By Day 4 you'll cross the Antarctic Convergence where the warmer subantarctic waters meet the colder Antarctic currents. During your days at sea, enjoy insightful presentations by the expedition team on topics such as photography, wildlife, glaciology and history. When not attending lectures, take advantage of time on deck to spot wildlife or relax with fellow travellers over a drink at the bar.
column69: As the vessel reaches the Antarctic Peninsula, the Captain and Expedition Leader will constantly assess the weather and ice conditions, looking for the best possible opportunities for your expedition. The intention is to head to the north-eastern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, into the little visited Weddell Sea. Each day on the Antarctic Peninsula will showcase the adaptability and expertise of your highly trained crew, both on the ship and in the air. During the course of your time in Antarctica the team will be aiming to offer three helicopter flights for all guests. Two of these will be flightseeing adventures of around 10-15 minutes in the air giving you incredible views of Antarctica's glacial beauty. The third excursion is intended to be a heli-landing, where the helicopter lands you in an otherwise inaccessible location.  However, please note that helicopter flights in Antarctica are highly dependent on the weather. This itinerary is designed to make sure every day is spent in breathtaking destinations that allow you to take to the skies when conditions allow or to maximise the wildlife and scenery you experience down on the ground on foot and by zodiac cruising if conditions are less than favourable for flight. If weather and ice conditions allow, you'll begin by sailing into the Antarctic Sound. Locations that you might explore here could include two towering geological landmarks: Madder Cliffs on Joinville Island and Brown Bluff at the northernmost tip of the Antarctic continent. There are large Adelie penguin colonies in the area, which you might explore via sturdy zodiac rib boat and gentoo penguins and seals are also often spotted along the coastline.You may have the chance to admire the distinctive 678-meter (2,225-foot) volcanic cliffs of Brown Bluff. If the weather cooperates, you might switch marine activities for your first flightseeing adventure of the trip, taking in the vastness of Antarctica from a snow petrel's perspective.As you continue through the Antarctic Sound and into Erebus and Terror Gulf, your Captain will strategically position the ship to make the most of both helicopter and zodiac excursions. The James Ross Island archipelago offers numerous opportunities to explore historically significant sites first trodden by humans during the Swedish Antarctic Expedition of 1901-04. Upon landing, the team will check conditions to offer a trek to a summit for panoramic views of an Adelie penguin colony and the northern Weddell Sea. Home to fossil discoveries and ventifacts (ancient rocks smoothed by wind and sand) this area is renowned for its geological importance. The team will aim to show you ventifacts up close, offering a deeper understanding of how wind erosion, driven by sand or ice particles, shapes the landscape over time.  Before heading back across the Drake Passage, there may be some time to explore the rugged South Shetland Islands.  The team will see if conditions allow for a scenic helicopter flight over Livingston Island, home of the South Shetlands' most sublime peaks. From the air, you might see the impressive Tangra Mountains, stretching 20 miles (32km) in length and 5 miles (8.5km) in width, along with the sky-scraping Mount Friesland, Bowles Ridge and Pliska Ridge.
column77: As you travel back across the Drake Passage, spend some time unwinding after all those adventures by land and air. The onboard spa is the ideal spot for a rejuvenating facial or massage. You can also relieve aching muscles in the sauna without missing any views – the floor-to-ceiling windows are perfect for gazing out to sea and watching passing seabirds.Your Antarctic educational programme also continues apace. Your team of onboard experts will keep sharing their extensive polar knowledge during scheduled lectures in the Ambassador Theatre. This is also a fantastic chance to pose any curious questions you may have about wildlife or geology you have seen or experienced during your expedition.
column84: Disembark in Ushuaia and fly to Buenos Aires
column85: You will arrive in Ushuaia in the morning and disembark after breakfast. After this, you will be whisked to the airport for your return flight to Buenos Aires.

column5: A streamlined wildlife-rich itinerary with a luxury focus. Sail straight to jaw-dropping South Georgia before continuing on to pristine Antarctica. Explore in comfort, indulging in exceptional cuisine and one-to-one service. Complimentary kayaking session and a hassle-free journey with return domestic charter flights are included.
column37: Day 1 of the voyage marks your scheduled departure for a flight to Puerto Williams, Chile, after which you'll board your ship, weather permitting.The price of your trip also covers a range of additional services designed for a seamless experience from beginning to end, including a pre-cruise night of accommodation in Santiago. Therefore, please make sure to arrive in Santiago at least one day prior to the outlined dates. On arrival in Chile's capital, make your own way to your included 5-star hotel in the city centre for an overnight stay. You then have free time to explore the city before the adventure begins in earnest tomorrow.
column45: Charter flight from Santiago to Puerto Williams
column46: Today, you'll be taken to the airport for your charter flight to petite Puerto Williams in southern Chile's Patagonia region. Here you will join your ship, meet your wonderful crew and set sail.
column60: These first days at sea allow ample time for your highly experienced expedition guides to brief you on the logistics of your journey. They'll inform you about the biosecurity rules to follow in South Georgia and Antarctica, and entertain you with educational lectures on everything from the history to the geology of these destinations, along with insights into the wildlife you will be encountering.  It's a great time to familiarise yourself with the ship, scoping out the plentiful amenities along with the spacious deck areas. Head out on deck to look for some of the Southern Ocean's most iconic seabirds, including albatross with vast wingspans and giant petrels cruising alongside the ship.
column69: Jagged mountains draped in snow, jaw-droppingly large glaciers and crowds of wildlife come together to create one of the world's most extraordinary islands: South Georgia. On beaches densely packed with wildlife, immerse yourself in the trilling sounds of thousands of king penguins, the various trumpets of belligerent elephant seals and the huffing of feisty fur seals. Once a remote whaling hub and now a heavily protected wildlife haven, South Georgia's history is both haunting and inspiring, especially as the location of the epic finale of Sir Ernest Shackleton's legendary Antarctic rescue. In 1916, the heroic polar explorer reached these shores on a small boat, seeking rescue for his crew shipwrecked 800 miles (1,300 km) away on Elephant Island. In Grytviken, a museum honours Shackleton's incredible journey and a grave in the small whalers' cemetery marks his final resting place. The island's iconic king penguins gather in thousands-strong rookeries and are recognisable by their vibrant orange markings or the fluffy brown kiwi-like chicks. But other birdlife abounds, whether it be macaroni penguins, grey headed albatross or the small cape petrel. During your time in South Georgia you may explore on foot or by shoreline safari using your sturdy zodiac rib boats. Exploring from the water's edge is perfect for when the beaches are too heavily crowded with seals and penguins to keep the mandatory 16 foot (5 metre) distance from the abundant wildlife.
column77: Days at sea are the ideal chance to unwind. Head to the well-equipped gym, treat yourself in tranquil spa or spend time whale watching out on the spacious deck – there's plenty to keep you occupied on your luxury ship. These moments are the perfect antidote to those busy days spent exploring on shore once you reach the landing areas scheduled in by the Captain and Expedition Leader. However, the educational programme will continue, with excellent talks from your expert guides preparing you for the wildlife, history and geology of Antarctica.
column85: The plan on this day is to pause at Elephant Island, a place said to have taken its name from the elephant seals glimpsed on its rocky terrain by early explorers. This location was not extensively navigated until Sir Ernest Shackleton's aforementioned expedition in 1916. Shackleton's crew found shelter on the volcanic shores after a daring escape from their ship Endurance, which was crushed by ice in Antarctica's Weddell Sea region. Your expedition guides will retell the epic story during your visit. While it's near impossible to land on the island due to the notoriously challenging conditions, you may get to ship cruise past Point Wild, where the expedition's 28 desperate crew members set up camp for 4.5 months. Have your binoculars at the ready to see if you can spot the small monument to their endeavour.
column92: Antarctica and the South Shetland Islands
column93: Antarctica's snow-shrouded landscapes and enormous ice formations make for an otherworldly experience. Untouched by people until 1820, the planet's least-explored continent offers the thrill of immersing yourself in the unknown. Everywhere you look, glaciers ripple down to the shoreline like icing pouring off a cake.  Mountain peaks stud the unique landscape, and small “dirty” looking marks from a distance often resolve into large rookeries of waddling penguins. Here you will be on the lookout for gentoo, chinstrap and perhaps even Adelie penguins. As you zodiac cruise around vast sculptural icebergs keep your eyes peeled for snoozing crabeater and Weddell seals and listen out for the blow of surfacing humpback whales. You might also visit the South Shetland Islands near the tip of the Peninsula. Here the scenery varies dramatically, with epic skylines and lunar landscapes formed by past volcanic activity.
column103: A renowned stretch of ocean, sailing the Drake Passage an epic and unforgettable experience. You're never alone on this legendary crossing as soaring seabirds will accompany your ship – head out to the stern decks to capture them cruising past on the thermals. The educational programme continues with more excellently delivered lectures and you also have time to reflect on your epic adventures and unwind before the journey home.
column111: As you approach civilisation after your time at sea, Puerto Williams shimmers into view. Here you'll disembark and say goodbye to your crew, expedition team and your ship. Your Antarctic adventure culminates with an included charter flight north to Santiago, where you can head home or continue your travels in South America.

column5: With an impressive 7 full days taking in Antarctica’s jaw-dropping landscapes, explore from the ultra comfort of your luxury vessel. Enjoy superb service from your highly trained onboard team – from the multiple dining venues to the well-equipped spa. For a truly unique polar experience, plunge beneath Antarctica’s surface on the ship’s state-of-the-art submarines.
column37: Today, you will take an included transfer from the airport for a pre-cruise stay at a luxurious hotel in the stylish capital of Argentina, Buenos Aires.
column46: This morning, you will join your fellow travellers on a ride to the airport. Here, you will board a charter flight for a scenic 3.5-hour journey down the length of Argentina to Ushuaia. The approach is breathtaking, as the port city is framed by towering snow-capped mountains.Upon arrival, you'll be greeted and transferred to the nearby port just a short distance away, where your ship waits. Once aboard, you'll cruise down the sparkling waters of the Beagle Channel. As you explore the spacious deck keep an eye out for your first exciting glimpses of birdlife soaring above.
column59: At sea crossing the Drake Passage
column60: As you journey across the legendary Drake Passage, navigating the waters between the tip of South America and the Antarctic Peninsula, your adventure truly begins. During these sea days, your expert expedition team of naturalists on board will prepare you for the thrilling experiences ahead. You will have the chance to attend practical briefings and fascinating educational presentations covering topics as varied as glacier formation, the history of Antarctica's earliest explorers, and the incredible wildlife you might soon encounter.Be sure to spend time out on deck, where you can spot magnificent seabirds such as albatrosses and giant petrels fluttering by. You may even have the chance to take part in Citizen Science sessions – perhaps contributing to cloud surveys. As your crossing nears its end, stay alert for your first sight of an Antarctic iceberg!
column69: Now the real adventure begins as you explore the wonderful landscapes and wildlife of the White Continent. Equipped with 24 sturdy zodiac boats that will whisk you ashore for landings, your ship is a purpose-built base for an expedition. On dry land, you may find yourself hiking through the snow to panoramic viewpoints or surrounded by penguins waddling their way from the sea to their colonies. The zodiacs are also ideal for cruising quietly through iceberg-strewn bays on the lookout for seals and whales.If you have booked an add-on activity, such as kayaking or a submarine dive, the onboard team will provide details of when these thrilling excursions will take place.Between landings, you will have ample time to rest and enjoy the ship's luxurious amenities. Attend an educational talk from one of the naturalists, soothe your senses in an outdoor jacuzzi or treat yourself to a rejuvenating massage in the spa. You can also simply sit and soak up the spectacular Antarctic scenery from your private balcony.As for the itinerary, your Captain and expedition leader will continually tweak the plans based on weather, ice conditions and any unexpected wildlife encounters. Each evening, you'll join a briefing on the next day's tentative schedule – but flexibility is key in this ever-changing environment.
column77: As you sail northwards towards Ushuaia, it's time to say goodbye to the extraordinary polar landscapes. Yet while your adventure is coming to a close, the expedition team will continue to offer captivating educational talks on various subjects relating to Antarctica. This is also a perfect time to unwind, reflect on your experiences and sort through the incredible photos you've taken – whether in the comfort of your suite or in one of the ship's inviting social areas.
column84: Disembarkation in Ushuaia and flight to Buenos Aires
column85: You will disembark the ship in Ushuaia this morning and transfer to the airport for your return flight to Buenos Aires. After being immersed in the wilderness of Antarctica, returning to civilisation can feel like quite the contrast. On arrival in Argentina's capital, you're free to continue with your onward travel plans, unforgettable memories in tow.

column5: A rare voyage sailing to two of the planet’s most spectacular wildernesses aboard a small, modern expedition ship. Admire Patagonia’s epic peaks and glacial fjords, including Chile's premier Torres del Paine National Park, before spending up to 5 full days exploring the Antarctic Peninsula. Complimentary kayaking excursion and camera gear rental included.
column37: Land in the Andes-backed Chilean capital and take a transfer from the airport to a downtown hotel for the one-night stay included in the voyage package. Settle in and take the guided tour of Santiago, where you'll be whisked to imposing sites such as the Plaza de Armas. This evening, a laid-back reception with a drink at the hotel provides the chance to ask any questions about the exciting journey ahead.
column45: Fly to Punta Arenas and embark on the ship
column46: Today, you will take a flight from Santiago to Punta Arenas, the Patagonian gateway city in southern Chile, before embarking on your waiting ship.
column59: Visit Karukinka Natural Park and Ainsworth Bay
column60: Cruise to Tierra del Fuego and venture into this archipelago's largest protected land area: Karukinka Natural Park. Visits to this private reserve – where you might enjoy a glimpse of Andean foxes, guanacos, black-browed albatrosses and more – are by special permission.You will also sail to Ainsworth Bay, a stunning fjord surrounded by subpolar forest, in the hopes of spotting the resident elephant seals.
column69: Local pilots will assist your Captain on the Bridge to expertly steer the ship as it wends its way through the winding Kirke Narrows. This area is only accessible to compact expedition vessels like yours. To cap off the adventure, you might take in the spectacular scenery by ship or wander around the lush nearby forests.
column76: Visit Puerto Natales and Torres del Paine National Park
column77: Early today you will stop in Puerto Natales before exploring the majesty of Torres del Paine National Park. This UNESCO Biosphere Reserve covers more than 550,000 acres and is home to a jaw-dropping range of geological forms – from sky-scraping granite pillars to jewel-toned lagoons. Look out for guanacos, rheas and armadillos as you trek amid the crystal-clear rivers and blue-tinted glaciers.
column85: Sailing through the Strait of Magellan leads to Francisco Coloane Marine Park, a 165,000-acre-strong swathe of stunning land and sea. Yet more wildlife is on the agenda here – keep a keen eye out for an eclectic mix of humpback whales, sea lions and Magellanic penguins. As your zodiac boat traces the coastline, you might even spot black and white Peale's dolphins or soaring Andean condors.
column93: Southern Patagonia's forest-topped islands, glassy lakes and snow-laden peaks are the mission today. The region's fjords are sliced between towering granite walls, while waterfalls spill down from high above. This is where you'll find Chile's “Glacier Alley”, part of the UNESCO-listed Cape Horn Biosphere Reserve. Sail into the hidden Pia Fjord with its astoundingly large glacier, then admire the scenery of Alberto de Agostini National Park, where the Andes and ocean meet. A monumentally tall wall of ice marks the edge of Garibaldi Glacier, which you might explore by zodiac or kayak. Next on the itinerary is Agostini Fjord, where you can often witness the thunderous sound of ice calving from the mountains above.
column102: At sea on the Drake Passage
column103: Embark on your voyage to Antarctica via the iconic Drake Passage. Out on deck, keep your eyes to the sky as a variety of seabirds will soar alongside the ship, including the majestic albatross. Your journey will be enriched by the engaging lectures from the onboard naturalists, who will share insights into the wildlife and geological wonders waiting for you on the Antarctic Peninsula.
column111: Thanks to this season's extended daylight hours, you'll have plenty of time to make the most of Antarctica. The flexible itinerary allows for spontaneous adventures, whether you're marvelling at playful whales just off the ship's bow or cruising among dazzling icebergs on an evening zodiac ride. One day, you could be paddling a kayak near gargantuan ice formations or strolling along a beach teeming with thousands of Adelie and gentoo penguins. The next, you might feel the excitement as the ship navigates through pack ice. Throughout your journey, the expert team of guides will continue to enhance every experience with their knowledge gleaned over multiple expeditions.
column119: Unwind on board and make the most of the ship's amenities as the coast of Antarctica disappears from view. If conditions allow on the way to Ushuaia in Argentina your Captain will navigate around the southernmost tip of South America at Cape Horn to witness the full force of the drama-fuelled meeting of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
column126: Disembark the ship and fly to Santiago
column127: Disembark and board your group charter flight to Santiago, where you can continue your travels in the region or begin your journey home.

column5: This extraordinary voyage offers a rare chance to immerse yourself in two of the planet’s wildest destinations on a comfortable, state-of-the-art expedition ship. Spend 4 or 5 days exploring the spectacular Antarctic Peninsula before the focus shifts to navigating Patagonia’s dramatic fjords and glaciers – including Chile's premier Torres del Paine National Park. Kayaking excursion and camera gear rental included.
column36: Arrive in Buenos Aires, Argentina, or Santiago, Chile
column37: Depending on the voyage date you have selected, you will either travel from Buenos Aires in Argentina or Santiago in Chile. Whichever colourful capital city is the launch point for your journey, you will be transferred from the airport to your hotel for a complimentary night's stay.
column45: Fly to Ushuaia and embark on your ship
column46: The next morning, your group will be taken to the airport for a flight to Ushuaia, the world's most southerly city. Your ship will be waiting for you in this Argentinean destination in a spectacular setting, nestled amid the spiky peaks of the Cordillera Darwin.While here, you'll pay a visit to the southern beech forest of Tierra del Fuego National Park, admiring trees much like those that shrouded the White Continent millennia ago. Lunch is served aboard a private catamaran today while you cruise the calm waters of the Beagle Channel in search of South American sea lions.Ushuaia's inhabitants often refer to their compact city as “El Fin Del Mundo” – translated from Spanish into “The End of the World” – but for you, it's merely the beginning.
column59: At sea on the Drake Passage
column60: These next two days will be spent sailing to Antarctica on the infamous Drake Passage. Head out on deck to breathe in the salty air if conditions permit – seabirds such as the mighty albatross, with the largest wingspan of any avian species – tend to glide along the wind currents churned up by your vessel. Indoors, you can attend one of the many lectures organised by the naturalist guides in your expedition team. This programme of talks will cover everything from the Antarctic Peninsula's wildlife to its geology.
column69: Long daylight hours offer plenty of opportunities for soaking up the Antarctic scenery. Your ship's itinerary will remain flexible so you can make the most of impromptu wildlife sightings. Perhaps you'll watch whales glide through the water right by the bow of your vessel or take in the evening light bouncing off the blue-hued icebergs in a glassy bay. From seeking out sleepy seals sprawled across the ice to walking on beaches among thousands of Adelie and gentoo penguins, there are plenty of memories to be made. Throughout it all, you will be accompanied by your professional and knowledgeable expedition guides.
column77: Unwind aboard your ship and enjoy its thoughtfully designed amenities as you say goodbye to the Antarctic. Your vessel will skirt South America's southernmost patch of land at Cape Horn, where the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans converge. Your next destination? Back to Ushuaia, where the Patagonian part of your tour begins.
column85: Your expedition will now venture deep into Southern Patagonia's starkly beautiful wilderness, a place of forest-ringed islands, placid lakes and snow-draped mountains. Dramatic fjords carve through impossibly high granite cliffs, while waterfalls cascade from lofty heights. Discover Chile's renowned “Glacier Alley” here, a centrepiece of the UNESCO-designated Cape Horn Biosphere Reserve. Next, navigate the secluded Pia Fjord, taking in its gargantuan glacier, then journey into Garibaldi Fjord within Alberto de Agostini National Park, where the Andes meet the ocean. You'll approach the imposing ice wall of Garibaldi Glacier aboard a zodiac boat or kayak for an up-close encounter then finish with a visit to Agostini Fjord, where you might even witness the thrilling and thunderous spectacle of ice calving from high above.
column92: Explore Puerto Natales and the Kirke Narrows
column93: Local pilots will join your Captain on the Bridge today to steer the ship though the winding Kirke Narrows, which are open only to small expedition vessels like yours.
column102: Enjoy Puerto Natales and Torres del Paine National Park
column103: Early this morning, your ship will dock in picture-perfect Puerto Natales, where you will head out to take in Chile's iconic Torres del Paine National Park. You'll either explore the best parts of this UNESCO Biosphere Reserve's 550,000 acres of rugged scenery by foot or vehicle.A mind-boggling range of geological forms are found here, from the lofty granite pillars of the “horns” and wind-carved grasslands to the blue-tinged glaciers and jewel-hued lagoons. Wildlife is also abundant – look out for guanacos, rheas and armadillos.
column110: Cruise through Francisco Coloane Marine Park
column111: The Strait of Magellan is your gateway to Francisco Coloane Marine Park. This area, the habitat of wildlife such as humpback whales, two species of sea lion and Magellanic penguins, covers over 165,000 acres of land and sea. Zig-zag along the coastline by zodiac and kayak, keeping a keen eye out for monochromatic Peale's dolphins and Andean condors.
column118: Explore Tierra del Fuego’s Karukinka Natural Park and Ainsworth Bay
column119: As your journey nears its end, sail to Tierra del Fuego's biggest protected land area: Karukinka Natural Park. This private reserve is only accessible by exclusive permission. Here, you can search for Andean foxes, guanacos, black-browed albatross and more before cruising to the lush forest-ringed Ainsworth Bay, yet another spectacular fjord, to look for elephant seals.
column126: Disembark the ship in Punta Arenas and fly to Buenos Aires or Santiago
column127: Today, you will leave the ship in the Chilean city of Punta Arenas and board your flight to Santiago or Buenos Aires, depending on the voyage date you have chosen. After this, you could continue your travels in the region or take an international flight home.

column5: Designed and led by women for women, this Antarctic voyage is the first of its kind. Fly over the Drake Passage with a close-knit group of no more than 130 like-minded female adventurers before exploring the White Continent on a state-of-the-art ship named after esteemed conservationist Dr Sylvia Earle. Optional activities, including polar snorkelling and kayaking, are available on this groundbreaking trip.
column37: Your trip begins in Punta Arenas, southern Chile, where you'll be met and transferred to your hotel in this city edging the historical Strait of Magellan. To make sure you feel fully prepared for the journey ahead, you'll attend a pre-embarkation briefing in the evening and have the opportunity to meet the other women joining your voyage.
column45: Fly to King George Island and embark on your ship
column46: This morning, you'll take a group transfer to the airport in Punta Arenas for your charter flight to King George Island. As your destination is one of the world's most remote, keep in mind that you'll need to be flexible as your plane could leave slightly before or after the scheduled time, depending on the weather. Your pilot needs a clear sky with perfect visibility for safe take-off and landing, and while most flights depart on the intended day, contingency measures will be in place if yours can't run as planned. After under two hours, you'll arrive in Antarctica, where your welcoming expedition team will usher you over to your waiting ship via zodiac. You'll have time to settle into your cabin before joining the mandatory safety briefings.
column60: Once you have landed on King George Island, the White Continent is yours for the taking. The plan over the next six days is to explore the Antarctic Peninsula's scenic western side and its equally beautiful South Shetland Islands. Your expedition team will adjust the itinerary according to the weather and ice conditions while making the most of the long daylight hours and any impromptu wildlife opportunities. Typically, your guides will attempt to take you on Antarctic landings and zodiac cruises twice a day. Layer up and enjoy sailing past sky-scraping ice cliffs or zig-zag around grounded icebergs, keeping a lookout for whales and seals en route. You might also pay a visit to bustling penguin rookeries, peruse the contents of wonderfully preserved historic huts and wander along spectacular snow-covered ridge lines. If you book one of the add-on activities in advance – such as kayaking, paddling, snorkelling or scuba diving – you'll have the opportunity to take part whenever conditions permit. As well as zodiac boat rides and onshore excursions, you might ship cruise some of the slender straits splitting offshore islands from the mainland. Or perhaps you'll stay awhile in scenic bays to watch whales gorging on krill. Listen out for the creaking and rumbling of glaciers as they calve their way from the mountains into the sea, too. As part of this voyage, the onboard lecture schedule will include educational talks on the key conservation work of women scientists, including: Dr Sylvia Earle, the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's first woman chief scientist. The esteemed conservationist has also been a National Geographic explorer-in-residence since 1998 and was named as Time Magazine's first ‘Hero of the Planet'.  Dr Carden Wallace AM, the Principal Scientist Emeritus at the Queensland Museum since 2014 and the first curator-director of the Museum of Tropical Queensland from 1987 to 2003. Wallace was part of the team that discovered the mass spawning of coral in 1984 and was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia in 2021. Joanna Ruxton, who Sir David Attenborough called “the person responsible for the plastic-free movement”. Along with working on the BBC's first Blue Planet documentary series, she also created the award-winning 2016 film A Plastic Ocean, depicting the impact of plastic waste on ocean ecosystems. Sharon Kwok, who launched the AquaMeridian Conservation & Education Foundation to inspire young people to protect and preserve the oceans. Kwok is also a Mission Blue and WildAid board member and Executive Director of the AquaMeridian Conservation & Education Foundation. Bernadette Demientieff, a tireless advocate for the rights of the Gwich'in people in northeast Alaska and northwest Canada. Demientieff also aims to protect the porcupine caribou herd's calving grounds in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge against destruction from oil and gas companies. Dr Asha de Vos, an ocean educator and pioneer of blue whale research in the northern Indian Ocean. The internationally renowned Sri Lankan marine biologist is the founder of Oceanswell, Sri Lanka's first marine conservation research and education organisation. Hanli Prinsloo, founder and executive director of I AM WATER, an ocean conservation foundation based in Cape Town, South Africa. As well as being a champion freediver, she helps children in under-served South African communities experience the sea's transformative qualities for the first time.
column68: Disembark and fly from King George Island to Punta Arenas
column69: As you approach Frei Base on King George Island, it's time to bid Antarctica goodbye before boarding your flight (around two hours) to Punta Arenas, Chile. From the airport here, you'll transfer to the group hotel for an overnight stay.
column77: After breakfast, bid a fond farewell to your fellow women travellers as you continue your onward journey, hopefully with a newfound sense of the immense power of nature. A transfer to the airport is included in your voyage fare.Please be aware that if your flight from Antarctica doesn't run on time because of the weather, you'll stay on your ship until you can return to Punta Arenas. We recommend that any departing flights you book out of Punta Arenas leave after midday today.
column85: NULL

column5: Experience the thrill of sailing across the legendary Drake Passage to Antarctica in one direction, then save time by returning to civilisation via a speedy 2 hour flight. Immerse yourself in the White Continent over 6 expedition days on a luxury all-inclusive ship with flawless service. Your complimentary kayaking excursion allows you to experience the true tranquillity of Antarctica.
column37: Land in Santiago, Chile's colourful capital, after an international flight and make your own way to your 5* city centre hotel for an included night's stay. Here you will receive the timings for your onward travel south tomorrow.
column45: Charter flight to Puerto Williams and embarkation
column46: You will be whisked to the airport for your domestic charter flight south to the Chilean town of Puerto Williams. Admire the dramatic backdrop of the Dientes de Navarino mountain range as you are taken to meet your luxurious expedition ship at the dock. Once aboard, your Antarctic adventure begins in earnest as you set sail towards Antarctica.
column60: As you cruise south across the infamous waters of the Drake Passage, the excitement builds with educational lectures preparing you for the wildlife, geology and history of the White Continent you will soon be exploring. Unwind in the spa and get to know the ship's wide variety of dining and social areas. Spend time out on deck watching seabirds such as mighty albatross following in the ship's wake, and as you draw closer to Antarctica, keep your eyes peeled for the exhilarating glimpse of your first iceberg.
column69: This ethereal destination, situated at the Antarctic Peninsula's northern tip and named after the first ship to navigate this passage in the early 1900s, is a visual feast. Gaze in awe at the enormous tabular icebergs broken off the Larsen Ice Shelf. They are sometimes so large they will dwarf your ship! Look for the splash of penguins porpoising through the water en route to their rookeries, or listen out for the memorable sound of surfacing humpback whales.  As a true expedition, there is no fixed itinerary for your time in Antarctica. Each day your experienced Captain and Expedition Leader will plot your off ship activities to make the most of the ever-changing weather and ice conditions, along with taking advantage of any impromptu wildlife encounters.
column77: The Antarctic Peninsula extends north, resembling an arm reaching towards South America. This striking landmass, 620 miles (998km) from the tip of the continent, is a spectacular introduction to Antarctica's vast, snow-laden landscapes and gargantuan glaciers.  Your Captain will expertly navigate the mesmerising maze of icebergs through endlessly dramatic landscapes. Your highly experienced expedition team of naturalists will be busy crafting a full schedule of activities, including time on shore to experience Antarctica in person. Whether you're watching the comical antics on show at bustling penguin colonies or weaving around the ice on a sturdy zodiac rib boat looking for marine wildlife, each day will bring new adventures. During your time exploring Antarctica the expedition team will aim to offer the opportunity for all interested guests to kayak. Gliding through the ice-strewn waters is often a highlight, with nothing but the sound of your paddle, the crackling ice and the calling of distant penguins to distract you from the jaw-dropping scenery. Between off-ship excursions, unwind and take in the incredible Antarctic views, whether out on deck, from the privacy of your own balcony or one of the many cosy social areas. Or treat yourself to a pampering session in the spa before indulging in a delectable meal at one of the ship's four dining venues. The beauty of this expedition is the luxury of choice to explore or relax as it suits your interests and energy levels each day.
column85: As you travel north towards the end of your voyage, you will stop to explore the geologically diverse and stunningly beautiful South Shetland Island chain located near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. A diverse range of wildlife resides in this remote area, from plump elephant seals to industrious gentoo penguins. Excursions here may include exploring the astounding volcanic landscapes, where the dark sand steams as you explore.
column92: King George Island - Flight to Puerto Williams, Chile
column93: Today, you'll say farewell to Antarctica and return to civilisation. Your charter flight will leave from the simple gravel airstrip when a safe operational weather window allows, so the departure time today is flexible. Once the flight takes off, the journey back to mainland South America takes around two hours – a time-saving shortcut compared with the alternative of two days' sailing back on the Drake Passage.After your Antarctic adventure, a night is included at a hotel in Puerto Williams. This buffer allows for any flight delays from King George Island and has the added benefit of helping you to slowly readjust to life back in the real world before heading further north.
column103: Today you will have a complimentary charter flight back to Santiago, which usually lands some time in the late afternoon or early evening. Please do factor in this relatively late arrival time when booking your onward travel. To avoid overly tight and stressful flight connections we strongly recommend arranging a final night in Chile's capital or perhaps extending your stay with a relaxing visit to nearby vineyards.

column5: Reduce travel time by flying south to Antarctica in just 2 hours. Experience the best of the White Continent over 6 days aboard a luxury all-inclusive ship with impeccable service and 5* facilities. Then enjoy the adventure of sailing back across the iconic Drake Passage for your return north to civilisation. A complimentary kayaking activity lets you experience Antarctica from a uniquely tranquil vantage point.
column37: Land in Santiago, Chile's capital, after an international flight and make your own way to your 5* hotel in the city centre for an included night's stay. Here you will receive information about the timings and logistics for tomorrow's charter flight to the country's south.
column45: Charter flight to Puerto Williams, Chile
column46: Today, you will be taken to the airport for your charter flight down to the Chilean town of Puerto Williams, the most southerly town in the world. On arrival, check in to your beautiful hotel ahead of tomorrow's anticipated plane journey to Antarctica. The team here will brief you on the expected logistics based on weather conditions on the runway in Antarctica, and provide you with the complimentary gear you need for your expedition.
column59: Flight to King George Island from Puerto Williams
column60: You will fly south from Puerto Williams to Antarctica today. Your comfortable charter flight is scheduled to land on a basic gravel airstrip on King George Island. This is only possible when a safe operational weather window permits, so your departure time will be flexible and could be brought forward or delayed - this will all be communicated locally. Once the plane takes off, the journey to Antarctica is just under two hours – a time-saving shortcut compared with the alternative of two days sailing on the Drake Passage, meaning you arrive fresh and ready for action. After disembarking your plane, a small vehicle will whisk you past the Chilean Frei research base to the shoreline.Your luggage will be transported straight from the plane to your cabin, so all you need to do is don your lifejacket and board a sturdy zodiac rib boat for the short journey to your waiting vessel. On board you will be introduced to your expert expedition team who will take you through some mandatory safety briefings before you set sail and the adventure begins in earnest.
column69: This enchanting destination, located at the Antarctic Peninsula's northern tip, is a visual feast. Prepare for your ship to be dwarfed by mammoth tabular icebergs split off from the Larsen Ice Shelf and listen for the splash of penguins porpoising through the water or the exhaling blows of humpback whales as they edge above the surface.  Just like the expeditions of polar explorers in bygone eras, there is no set itinerary for your tour of Antarctica. Your highly experienced Captain and Expedition Leader will plan your off ship excursions to maximise the opportunities offered by the often mercurial weather and ice conditions, as well as take advantage of any impromptu wildlife encounters.
column77: The dramatic landscapes of the Antarctic Peninsula provide a spectacular introduction to the White Continent's snow-shrouded landscapes and colossal glaciers. The Captain will expertly navigate the sparkling labyrinth of icebergs in the most jaw-dropping and mind-boggling landscape you can imagine. Your highly experienced expedition team of naturalist guides will also be busy crafting a full schedule of activities, including off ship excursions to fully immerse yourself in Antarctica. Whether you're catching the chuckle-inducing antics of penguins at busy rookeries or pushing through brash ice from your zodiac rib while looking for whales and seals, no one day is the same as the next. During your time exploring, your expedition team will aim to organise a kayaking excursion for all guests keen to glide serenely across Antarctica's ice-scattered waters. This is often called out as a trip highlight by past travellers, who loved hearing nothing but the sound of their paddle and the muffled calls of distant penguins while taking in the memorable scenery. When not taking part in thrilling off ship excursions, the ship is a perfect platform for relaxing while always soaking up the incredible landscapes surrounding you. Head out on deck to look for passing wildlife or to photograph ice drifting by, or warm up with a hot drink in one of the several cosy social areas. Pamper yourself with a treatment at the spa or simply revel in the magic from the seclusion of your private balcony.
column85: As the ship swings north and the finale of your trip draws closer, you will pause to experience the geologically diverse and wildly beautiful South Shetland Islands chain near the top of the Antarctic Peninsula. Excursions here may include stepping foot on the otherworldly volcanic sand landscapes home to a smorgasbord of wildlife – from hefty elephant seals to energetic gentoo penguins.
column93: As you cruise north across the legendary waters of the Drake Passage – a rite of passage on any polar expedition – the educational lectures on the wildlife, geology and history of the White Continent will continue. Head out on deck to wonder at the huge wingspan of albatross and giant petrels which often shadow the ship as it sails towards civilization. You can also take the time to enjoy the ship's facilities during these last few days at sea, from the sumptuous spa to the large variety of dining and social areas. It's the perfect time to reflect and take stock of everything you have experienced.
column102: Disembark in Puerto Williams and fly to Santiago, Chile
column103: Marking the end of your Antarctic voyage, you will take a complimentary charter flight from the town of Puerto Williams in southern Chile and fly back to the country's capital. Your plane will likely land in the late afternoon or early evening. Please do factor in this relatively late arrival time when organising your onward travel. To prevent stressful flight connections, we advise booking a final night in Santiago or perhaps lengthening your trip with an excursion to nearby vineyards to defrost and decompress before returning home.

column5: A time-saving voyage to the 7th Continent, this action-packed trip makes the most of 3 full days touring the highlights of Antarctica. Aboard your spacious, purpose-built expedition ship, sail comfortably in polar waters with just 130 fellow travellers. Optional excursions including kayaking and snorkelling enhance the experience.
column37: After touching down in the world's southernmost city, you will be met at Ushuaia airport and transferred with your fellow travellers to a hotel for a complimentary night's stay. There will be an opportunity to get any lingering questions about your embarkation tomorrow answered or request advice on where to eat that evening. You will also confirm whether you want to join tomorrow's complimentary tour of nearby Lake Escondido.
column46: This morning, fuel up with a complimentary breakfast. If you have decided to join the complimentary Lake Escondido tour, you're in for a treat. This excursion offers stunning views of the Andes mountain range's vast glacial valleys, surrounded by varied evergreen and deciduous forests brimming with waterfalls and rivers. The tour will leave the city of Ushuaia and wend through peat-bog valleys towards Garibaldi Pass. From here, soak up panoramic vistas of crystal-clear Lake Escondido. If the skies are blue, you might even see all the way across to Fagnano Lake, your next port of call. You will descend to this body of water to visit a local ranch and enjoy a regional classic barbecue of Fuegian Lamb before heading back to Ushuaia to embark on your ship. If you would prefer to skip the tour, you have free time to explore the city, perhaps visiting the quirky Maritime Museum before meeting at the hotel lobby for a transfer to the pier. Once onboard the vessel, settle into your cabin before attending the mandatory safety briefings. As the ship leaves port, your fellow travellers will gather on deck to kickstart your Antarctic adventure as Ushuaia and its surrounding Tierra del Fuego province become a tiny speck on the horizon.    This evening, mingle with your fellow expeditioners at a special dinner to celebrate the beginning of your exhilarating voyage to the White Continent.
column60: Your well-equipped ship is a comfortable space to spend two days crossing the Drake Passage. En route learn more about Antarctica by attending the immersive educational lectures organised by your expert expedition team. Here you can build up your knowledge of the White Continent's history, wildlife and environment, and attend vital briefings on biosecurity, wildlife-watching guidelines and zodiac safety ahead of your first landing. In between lectures and briefings there will be time to enjoy the gym, wellbeing centre or library, and we also recommend getting out on deck to enjoy the huge seabirds such as albatross and giant petrels, which can often be spotted gliding along past the ship. Your ship may run citizen science projects including seabird surveys and cloud surveys, which are well worth getting involved with.On day four, the air will begin to crackle with anticipation as your ship skirts the South Shetland Islands and tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. South of the Antarctic Convergence, head out on deck to catch your first glimpse of an iceberg. You might even spot the splash of porpoising penguins in the sea and, if time and favourable weather conditions allow, you may even step foot on land during the late afternoon.
column69: Breathe in the crisp polar air and get ready to explore the majestic South Shetland Islands and the north-western side of the Antarctic Peninsula. Your highly experienced Expedition Leader and Captain will craft your daily itinerary. They will choose the best routings and activities based on the weather and ice conditions, along with taking advantage of impromptu chances to spot incredible wildlife. Generally, landings or zodiac excursions will occur up to twice a day. Wrap up warm to head out on the sturdy zodiac rib boats and take in towering ice cliffs and grounded icebergs, keeping an eye out for whales and seals en route.
