The zodiacs will also whisk you from ship to shore, where you can experience the comical joy of waddling penguins moving along their “highways”. While ashore you might have the opportunity to explore along ice-strewn beaches or hike up to viewpoints for breathtaking views. If you have booked an optional activity (at additional cost), such as kayaking or snorkelling, the onboard team will organise for you to take part when conditions permit. The team will also be looking out for suitable conditions to offer the polar plunge, where you can tick off the bucket-list experience of braving the icy Antarctic waters - for a very brief moment! Additionally, you might cruise by ship along slender straits splitting offshore islands from the mainland. Or stay for a while in beautiful bays where the ship is the perfect platform to watch in awe as whales gorge on the krill-rich sea. Antarctica is a destination that awakens all the senses, so listen out for the thunderous rumble of glaciers as they calve from heavily crevassed faces into the sea, birthing icebergs. If you're feeling chilly, you can also enjoy the icy scenery through the large windows of the cosy observation lounge.
column76: Sail back across the Drake Passage
column77: Should conditions allow there might be the opportunity to squeeze in one final landing this morning on the South Shetland Islands before your ship returns to South America via the legendary Drake Passage. The excellent educational programme will continue during these two days, adding yet more depth to your Antarctic experience. When not expanding your knowledge, immerse yourself in the grandeur of the Southern Ocean one last time. Marvel at the huge wingspan of the mighty albatross as it follows the wake of the ship and breathe in the salty sea air while you witness the power of the ocean. As you approach the tip of South America, your Captain might attempt a distant sail-by of notorious Cape Horn, weather and time permitting.
column85: Having sailed back up the picturesque Beagle Channel, this morning you ship will slip into dock in Ushuaia, ready for you to disembark at around 8am. Say goodbye to your expedition team and fellow adventurers as you continue your journey around the region or homeward bound. We recommend any onward flights are booked after midday today, to allow a buffer for any delays returning from Antarctica.

column5: With spectacular architecture, a world-class food scene and irresistible energy, Buenos Aires is a city that invites you to stay longer. Add another stamp to your passport as you combine Argentina's capital with a day in Colonia, Uruguay. Cross the mighty La Plata River to the UNESCO World Heritage old town and wander its charming cobbled streets and colonial squares.
column37: On arrival in Buenos Aires, your guide will whisk you by private transfer to your perfectly placed hotel. After you settle in, head out to enjoy the city's warmth as you explore the surrounding area. Listen to the neighbourhood hum with life while pausing for an aromatic cafe con leche and perfectly baked empanada as a first taste of Argentina.  Meals: None included
column45: Get to know the city on an in-depth tour
column46: This morning, embark on a guided city tour taking in the sights and sounds of Buenos Aires. As you explore, your local English-speaking guide will introduce you to Argentina's rich history – from Spanish colonisation and the struggle for independence to the tumultuous dictatorships and return to democracy. While the route will vary depending on events in the city, a visit to the elegant Recoleta district, which has a Parisian feel, is a true highlight. Stop in the historic centre of San Telmo and the Plaza del Armas, the heart of colonial Buenos Aires, and soak up the vibrancy of the La Boca neighbourhood known for its colourful street art and immigrant roots. Finally, take in the gleaming skyline of the modern riverfront Puerto Madero area.This afternoon you're free to explore independently. Perhaps pay a visit to the renowned Ateneo Grand Splendid, once a grand theatre and now regularly referred to as the world's most beautiful bookstore. Or while the afternoon away among the scents of the 6,000 tree and plant species in the lush green botanical gardens. This evening is the perfect chance to frequent a parrilla and savour the authentic Argentinean taste of tantalisingly juicy steak grilled over an open flame. Excursion: Five-hour city tour on a private basisMeals: Breakfast at your hotel
column59: Get a taste of Uruguay with a day in Colonia del Sacramento
column60: Today, an early pickup from your hotel will take you to the ferry port, where your driver will help with check-in and direct you towards departures. After getting your passport stamped, embark on the boat for a leisurely 75-minute journey crossing the Rio de la Plata, one of South America's great rivers, before arriving in Uruguay. In contrast to the buzz of Buenos Aires, Colonia's cobbled streets are like stepping back in time. Your local guide will meet you on arrival and take you past ivy-covered buildings and around a charming town square as they share with you tales of Uruguay's absorbing past. Feel yourself immediately slow down to a different pace of life, and after the tour, enjoy an afternoon wandering the serene town or lingering at the riverfront.In the afternoon your guide will help you check in for the return journey, and you'll sail back into Buenos Aires in the late afternoon light. Soak up the views of the city as you approach the harbour, the modern cityscape a stark contrast to the old world you just left behind. Once docked, your driver will meet you and take you back to your hotel for a final restful night in Argentina's capital.Excursion: Full-day trip to Colonia de Sacramento, including transfers and ferry tickets, with town tour on a shared or private basisMeals: Breakfast at your hotel
column69: When it's time to travel onward, a private transfer will collect you from your hotel and usher you to the airport in time for your flight.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel
column77: NULL
column85: NULL

column3: Crossing the Antarctic Circle Fly & Cruise
column5: Expedite your trip to the Antarctic Circle by flying across the Drake Passage in just 2 hours. Spend an immersive 8 full days exploring the Antarctic Peninsula, including a visit below 66°33′ latitude aboard a comfortable, state-of-the-art expedition ship. Optional activities like kayaking and polar snorkelling are available for active adventurers.
column37: After arriving in this Chilean port city, you will be met and whisked off to your downtown hotel. Overlooking the Straits of Magellan, Punta Arenas straddles one of Earth's most historic trade routes. Today, it reflects a wonderful blend of cultures, from British sheep ranchers to Iberian sailors, and is an intriguing introduction to Chile's rich history.Tonight, you will meet your fellow travellers during a briefing focused on the first part of your expedition: the flight to Antarctica! You will be advised locally of the anticipated timings and logistics for your flight, as this will be dependent on the weather conditions.
column46: Today a transfer will take you to Punta Arenas airport for your charter flight to Antarctica's King George Island. The plane journey will take around two hours.On arrival at King George Island, your expedition team will greet you and guide you onto a zodiac for the short transfer to your waiting ship. The airstrip at King George Island, part of the South Shetland Islands at the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula, is one of the most remote destinations on the planet. Clear skies and perfect visibility are needed for safe takeoff and landing, so please keep in mind that delays are possible.
column59: Exploring the Antarctic Peninsula and below the Antarctic Circle
column60: Exploring Antarctica is an experience that is so intoxicating, it is difficult to describe. The sight of your first iceberg and the feeling of inhaling some of the freshest, crispest air on Earth will stay with you for the rest of your life. During your eight days you will be exploring the dramatic landscapes and wildlife of the South Shetland Islands, the western side of the Antarctic Peninsula and below the Antarctic Circle. The highly experienced experts in your expedition team and your talented Bridge team will use their knowledge to craft the perfect daily itinerary. They will work with the weather, ice conditions and wildlife opportunities to ensure you make the most of your adventure.Typically, you will make landings or head out on zodiac excursions up to twice a day, cruising past grounded icebergs, keeping an eye out for whales, seals and penguins. Zodiacs also provide access to the shore, where you might visit bustling penguin rookeries, watching these raucous birds raise their young.Ashore, there will be opportunities to wander across ice-strewn beaches or perhaps up snow-shrouded hills to panoramic viewing points with jagged mountain peaks towering overhead. Pre-booked optional activities such as kayaking, paddling and snorkelling will take place whenever conditions allow, and for the bold, the polar plunge offers a full-body immersion in frigid Antarctic waters! Between excursions enjoy the views from out on the spacious decks or from the large windows of the observation lounge. Listen out for the thunderous rumbles of glaciers as they calve, and take a moment to reflect on the wonder and immensity of the White Continent.During this voyage, weather and ice conditions permitting, the plan is to cross the Antarctic Circle – an imaginary line at approximately 66°33' South. For many, reaching this far is a true highlight, and you will mark the moment with a celebratory toast on deck (weather allowing). It is an achievement few can claim and will earn you a place among the lucky adventurers who have experienced this remote part of the world.As the ship approaches and crosses the Antarctic Circle, subtle changes in the landscape and wildlife become apparent. At this time of year, the waters are rich with krill, attracting an abundance of marine life. So keep your eyes peeled for the blows of passing humpbacks and minkes.
column68: Disembark at King George Island and fly to Punta Arenas
column69: As you head north and approach Frei Base on King George Island, say goodbye to Antarctica and your wonderful team. Here you will board the return flight to Chile's Punta Arenas. After your 2 hour flight, on arrival back in civilisation you will be ushered to a downtown hotel to wind down from your journey during a final complimentary night's stay.
column77: After breakfast, bid adieu to your fellow passengers and continue your onward travels, either home or towards your next destination in South America. We recommend not booking any onward flight to Santiago before 2pm.
column85: NULL

column5: With 4 full days exploring the Antarctic Peninsula, gain a deeper understanding of this unique environment on this discovery-focused itinerary. Get hands on with citizen science projects contributing to polar research and learn more in the onboard science hub. Included return charter flights from Buenos Aires to Ushuaia make for hassle free travel, and camping, kayaking and paddleboarding are available as optional activities.
column37: Land in Argentina's cosmopolitan and charismatic capital and make your own way to your hotel for a night's stay, which is included as part of your travel package.
column45: Flight to Ushuaia and embarkation day
column46: After a complimentary breakfast at your hotel early this morning, you will be transferred to the airport to take your included group charter flight to Ushuaia, the world's southernmost city. On arrival, you will be whisked from the airport to a central downtown location. With the Beagle Channel stretching to the south and snow-dusted mountains to the north, this is a spellbinding departure point for your Antarctic cruise. Enjoy free time exploring the eclectic port city before making your own way to the meeting spot by late afternoon for your transfer to the ship. After embarkation, you will cruise out of the Tierra del Fuego archipelago and towards the White Continent!
column60: During these days at sea, your onboard expedition team will keep you busy with briefings aimed at preparing you for the adventure ahead. They will also host captivating lectures on the wildlife, ice and history of Antarctica as part of the ship's in-depth educational programme. Your vessel features a science hub, where you can interact with digital displays showcasing multimedia content. Learn how data collection methods, from wildlife tags to guano sampling, allow polar researchers to study the health, population and migratory pathways of polar wildlife. You can also discuss observations, and once you're in Antarctica, inspect samples collected during scientific zodiac cruises.When you're not learning about the White Continent, step out on deck with a camera and binoculars in hand – this is the ideal place for your first wildlife sightings, from enormous albatrosses to curious giant petrels. As you journey into the Drake Passage, remember that the next time you see land, you'll be approaching the world's southernmost continent!
column68: Exploring the Antarctic Peninsula and the South Shetland Islands
column69: When you arrive in the Antarctic, your adventure truly begins. With your skilled Captain and Expedition Leader adapting plans to work with the ever-changing weather and ice conditions, as well as make the most of unexpected wildlife encounters, each day will bring something new.The experts in your expedition team are there to help you appreciate this majestic continent. You'll step onshore to witness the lively chaos of penguin rookeries, glide past sculptural icebergs on zodiac cruises, and watch out for incredible marine life – perhaps sleepy seals lounging on ice floes or humpback whales gorging on krill.If you have signed up for optional activities in advance, such as kayaking or paddleboarding, the team will organise these excursions during your days in Antarctica.During the evenings, your naturalist guides will offer insights into the wildlife behaviours you observed on your outings, while your Expedition Leader will share the initial plan for the next day.Whenever you have a free moment, step out onto the ship's spacious decks, perhaps taking in the awe-inspiring icy landscapes that encircle you while keeping an eye out for the blow of passing whales. relaxing on the heated benches.
column77: As you cross this iconic sea route on your journey back to civilisation, take in the refreshing Southern Ocean air a few final times. Spot seabirds fluttering through the skies, scan the waves in search of whales, join engaging presentations from your expedition team and reminisce about the unforgettable moments you have experienced in Antarctica's wilderness.
column84: Disembarkation in Ushuaia and flight to Buenos Aires
column85: Your ship will slip into dock in Ushuaia by this morning, ready for you to disembark after breakfast. You will then take a transfer to the airport for your group charter flight to Buenos Aires.From here you can make your own onward travel arrangements, but please check timings before booking international flights out of Argentina.

column5: Passing through Buenos Aires and only have time for a short stop? Make the most of the city's grand colonial landmarks and lively Latin American culture with this action-packed itinerary. You’ll stay centrally to enhance your experience, giving you an inspiring snapshot of Argentina's eclectic capital – and plenty of reason to return.
column36: Take in the highlights of the city

Your English-speaking Swoop guide will greet you at the airport and transfer you by private vehicle to your centrally located hotel.Later today, dive straight into Latin America's absorbing culture. Your local guide will pick you up from your hotel for an introduction to the city's highlights and history. Visit the 500-year-old downtown area, where the pink-hued presidential palace contrasts against the lush green trees of Plaza de Mayo, then admire the rainbow of murals in La Boca. Here, your guide will educate you on the history of Argentina's original immigrant populations and how they shaped the city today.For this evening's entertainment, why not speak to our team at Swoop about booking a tango show? Enjoy the rhythmic melodies as you watch professional dancers put on a mesmerising display of traditional culture. Excursions: Private three-hour city tour Meals: None included
column46: Depending on your flight time, use this morning to explore your local neighbourhood. Amble along wide boulevards lined with neoclassical buildings in Recoleta, which lend Buenos Aires its ‘Paris of South America' nickname, or watch life bustle around you as you sip coffee in one of Palermo's picture-perfect squares. Your private transfer will collect you and take you to the airport in time for your onward flight. Meals: Breakfast in your hotel

column5: Experience the best of Buenos Aires with an itinerary that blends the must-see sights with lesser-visited highlights. Discover the city's rich history and diverse neighbourhoods – from upscale Recoleta to hip La Boca – on a guided tour followed by an exhilarating evening out. Taken at a comfortable pace, this popular itinerary strikes an ideal balance between guided activities and time for your own discovery.
column36: Start your adventure in Buenos Aires
column37: After you land in this expansive city, your English-speaking guide will greet you at the airport and usher you by private vehicle to your centrally located hotel. The afternoon is left free to discover the surrounding area at leisure. Why not ask your guide for dinner recommendations from the exceptional choice of nearby restaurants? From sizzling steaks to melt-in-the-mouth provoleta cheese, there are plenty of authentic Argentinean delights to try. Meals: None included
column45: Highlights of the city and evening out
column46: Today, soak up the highlights of  South America's most European city on a guided tour. While the exact order might vary, stops are planned at the elegant Recoleta district to wander the elegant tree-lined boulevards and explore the historical centre where this colonial town was founded. Lively La Boca, with its brightly painted zinc shacks, is another itinerary highlight, along with the skyscraper-studded Puerto Madero riverfront. With a choice of two exceptional dining experiences, including private transfers, this evening will be one to remember. If tango is on your bucket list, take in a scintillating professional show at an intimate low-lit theatre with a live orchestra and three-course dinner. Alternatively, join a hands-on group cooking experience where your energetic hosts will introduce you to Argentina's fabulous food and drink culture. column5: Enjoy an energising stay in one of South America’s liveliest cities. The thriving metropolis of Buenos Aires is the perfect destination for active explorers. Lush parks, scenic cycle paths and charming walkable streets invite you to immerse yourself in Argentina’s outdoor culture before or after setting sail.
column36: Arrival in Buenos Aires and street food tour
column37: After you land in Argentina's capital, your local guide will greet you at the airport and transfer you by private vehicle to your centrally located hotel. Settle in at your comfortable base before joining a small-group walking and food tour of the city's hip Palermo area. Make sure to arrive hungry as you'll weave through the neighbourhood's charmingly narrow streets, indulging in some of the best flavours in Buenos Aires. Your local guide will provide a fascinating introduction to Argentina's dining culture, showcase the local street art and explain how the city's most bohemian district became such an icon. Excursions: Small-group walking food tour with 11 samples over four restaurant stops Meals: Dinner on a walking food tour
column45: Bicycle tour of historic Buenos Aires
column46: Today, a private transfer will take you to the historic San Telmo area, the birthplace of Argentina's capital. Here, meet your cycling guide, who will be ready and waiting to show you around their home. They will provide you with a bike and helmet, and once everyone is comfortable, the adventure begins. Moving with the bustle of the city, you'll soon be immersed in local life. The tour will make stops to take in the multicoloured zinc houses of La Boca, eat a delectable lunch at the street food stalls of El Caminito, admire the towering skyscrapers of Puerto Madero, and cross the asymmetric Women's Bridge to finish in the heart of the city at Plaza de Mayo.Excursions: Private cycling tour of Buenos Aires' old town Meals: Breakfast at your hotel; street food lunch on cycling tour
column60: Depending on your flight time, you can use this morning to explore Buenos Aires' most stylish district. Amble down Recoleta's leafy boulevards, past the neoclassical architecture, and admire the intricately carved crypts in the renowned cemetery, famed as the resting place of legendary political activist Evita. Ahead of your onward flight, a private transfer will collect you and take you to the airport.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Sample Argentina’s incredible flavours – from juicy barbecue to flaky empanadas – on this culinary-themed city break. Get to know Buenos Aires intimately while sightseeing with your English-speaking guide. Dine your way through the city on a walking food tour, then feast on an exquisite tasting menu made up of the capital's best dishes.
column36: Start your adventure in Buenos Aires

Explore historic San Telmo – the birthplace of colonial Buenos Aires – and visit the lively La Boca neighbourhood, known for its colourful street art and immigrant beginnings. You'll also take in the modern skyline of the riverfront Puerto Madero area. With a visit to the renowned asado restaurant of Fogón planned, this evening will be one to remember. Here, an exquisite tasting menu, artfully prepared in the central open kitchen, demonstrates the best of Argentinian cuisine. Taste local delicacies such as melt-in-the-mouth provoleta cheese before a feast of sizzling meat courses showcasing why Buenos Aires is truly South America's number one destination for barbecue. Excursions: Five-hour city tour of Buenos Aires on a small group or private basis Meals: Breakfast at your hotel; dinner at Fogón restaurant

Alternatively, mingle with the locals as they cycle, skate and jog in one of the city's manicured parks. When it's time to travel onward, a private airport transfer will collect you from your hotel and take you to the airport in time for your onward flight.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Ease into your Antarctic adventure – or unwind afterwards – with a relaxing escape in rural Argentina. Just a short trip from Buenos Aires, a stay at an authentic country estate allows you to slow down and breathe in the fresh air of the Pampas Plain. Immerse yourself in estancia life, where gaucho traditions will lend a unique twist to your travel in South America.
column36: Arrive in Argentina and transfer to the ranch
column37: On arrival in Buenos Aires, you'll be met by your private transfer and whisked out of the city as you head toward your estancia – your home for the next two nights. Depending on your chosen accommodation, the journey will take between one and three hours, so sit back, relax and watch as the urban landscape gives way to sweeping countryside and vast stretches of farmland.At the estate, your hosts will welcome you with a cool drink and a tour of the historic residence. You'll have a chance to explore the activities available and plan your stay to match your interests. Here in the low grassland plains, horse riding and gaucho traditions are at the heart of local culture. During your visit, you can enjoy horseback or carriage riding through the estate's expansive grounds. You could also borrow a bike, join a cooking class or simply wander through the peaceful gardens and relax beside the pool.This evening, enjoy a delicious three-course dinner and the warm hospitality of your hosts. Excursions: A selection of activities, as chosen during check-inMeals: Three-course dinner with wine
column46: Start your day with a delightful breakfast crafted with homemade preserves and fresh produce from the estate. The house is a historic family home, and your hosts will be happy to share tales of its past residents. This morning, you might set off on a leisurely bicycle adventure around the grounds, take a tour of the vegetable gardens or learn how to make local specialities such as empanadas (traditional savoury pastries) during a cooking class. Lunch is a real treat: a traditional Argentinian asado, a sociable staple of rural cuisine. Meat is grilled over a fire and served with a spread of potatoes, salads and vegetables – paired, of course, with plenty of Argentinian Malbec. In the afternoon, unwind by the pool, soaking in the peaceful sounds of birds in the trees, or join a horseback ride through the estate while learning about the gaucho way of life.Excursions: A selection of activities, as chosen during check-inMeals: Breakfast, asado lunch, afternoon tea and dinner with wine
column60: Start the morning with a leisurely breakfast and perhaps a final dip in the pool before your driver picks you up and transfers you to the airport for your onward travel. Meals: Breakfast at the estate

column5: Experience Ushuaia, the gateway to both Antarctica and the untamed wilderness of Tierra del Fuego, on a rejuvenating short stay. If your time is limited, this overnight break, complete with hassle-free transfers and a guided national park tour, offers a satisfying taste of this Patagonian wonder.
column37: Touch down in Ushuaia, regularly referred to as the world's southernmost city, where the spectacular snow-capped Martial Mountains spill down to the sparkling waters of the Beagle Channel. Your private guide will meet you at the airport and transfer you to your comfortable hotel. After settling in, enjoy a stroll along the picture-perfect waterfront or through the city centre to pick up any last-minute items you need for your Antarctic adventure. En route to the hotel, why not ask your guide for restaurant recommendations? Distinctive local delicacies include the city's iconic king crab and melt-in-the-mouth Fuegian lamb. Meals: None included
column46: This morning, embark on a tour of Tierra del Fuego National Park, exploring its thick forests, shimmering lakes and rugged mountains. For your visit, you have a choice of experiences. Either wind your way slowly through the jaw-dropping scenery on a small steam train or have your guide drive you straight into the heart of the park, where you can hike up to scenic viewpoints overlooking the wild grandeur. After your tour, you'll return to Ushuaia and have time to explore independently until your private transfer arrives for your onward journey.Excursion: Tierra del Fuego National Park tour on a shared or private basisMeals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Sandwiched between the shimmering Beagle Channel and snow-capped Martial Mountains, Ushuaia is more than just a gateway to Antarctica. The cold nutrient-rich waters teem with fresh seafood, while the local barbecue culture offers rich flavours. This tantalising blend has transformed the city into an emerging foodie hotspot.
column37: Arrive in Ushuaia, the world's southernmost city, and meet your Swoop guide, who will take you by private transfer to your hotel. After settling in, enjoy a leisurely stroll along the windswept waterfront, set against a stunning backdrop of snow-capped mountains rising up against the vast Patagonian sky. For an introductory taste of the region, why not ask your guide where to find the best local flavours, from succulent king crab to tender Fuegian lamb?Meals: None included
column45: Fishing village and Beagle dining experience
column46: Today, pay a visit to the village of Puerto Almanza, the hub of Ushuaia's king crab industry and the home of Diane, your host for the day.After a pickup from your hotel, you'll follow the dramatic spine of the soaring mountains into the wild landscape of Tierra del Fuego. Stop for a rejuvenating lakeside coffee, admiring the sparkling water as you sip, and visit the famous flag trees, their gnarled trunks and twisted limbs manipulated by the power of the Patagonian wind. Leaving the car, you'll take a short walk down a winding forest trail surrounded by ancient subantarctic trees and arrive at Diane's waterside house overlooking the rippling sea below. Your host will welcome you in with a refreshing glass of local wine and unveil the menu of the day. Enjoy a spectacular five-course lunch made from local ingredients caught in the surrounding ice-cold waters and foraged from the fertile land. As you eat, Diane and your guide will share stories about fishing in the Beagle Channel and how local life is shaped by these southern waters. Meals: Breakfast at your hotel, lunch at Diane's cottageExcursions: A gastronomic experience with local seafood on a shared or private basis
column60: Your final day in Ushuaia is ideal for some shopping or a visit to one of the quirky local museums. Wander through the centre to pick up any last-minute essentials for your Antarctic trip, or speak to your Swoop expert to add on a morning visit to the majestic lakes and mountains of Tierra del Fuego National Park.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Traditionally seen as simply a gateway destination for Antarctic adventurers, Ushuaia deserves far more than a passing glance. Set on the shimmering Beagle Channel and backed by imposing snow-sprinkled mountains, this port city is the perfect launchpad for exploring the spectacular surrounding Tierra del Fuego region.
column37: On arrival in Ushuaia, your guide will meet you and usher you by private transfer to your centrally located hotel. After checking in, amble along the harbour and watch the ship crews prepare for their next Antarctic voyages.Alternatively, wander through the city centre, stopping off to enjoy a locally brewed craft beer and the cosy atmosphere in a cerveceria (pub).Meals: None included
column45: Exploring Tierra del Fuego National Park
column46: Today, you can look forward to a half-day tour of Tierra del Fuego National Park. After a short drive from the hotel, pass through the park entrance and explore in the way that suits you best. One option is to chug along on the iconic End of the World steam train, spending a leisurely hour admiring the soul-stirring views as you wind your way through the first section of the park. On arrival at the station, you'll rejoin your guide and take in key viewpoints overlooking jewel-like lakes and sky-scraping mountains.Alternatively, for an intimate encounter with the wilderness, travel straight to a quiet section of the park for a guided hike, learning about the region's distinctive flora and fauna as you wander. This afternoon is left free for you to explore Ushuaia. Make the most of your guide's insider knowledge by asking for their favourite spots to try Ushuaia's famous king crab or traditional lamb. Excursion: Tierra del Fuego National Park tour on a shared or private basisMeals: Breakfast at your hotel
column60: On your final morning in Ushuaia, you could visit the Maritime Museum to learn about the region's layered history – from its Indigenous communities and days as the Siberia of the South penal colony to its transformation into a contemporary tourism hub. When the time comes, you'll be picked up by private transfer for your onward travel.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Combine a visit to modern Ushuaia with a hike through the ancient wilderness of Tierra del Fuego. A short drive from the Antarctic gateway city, you’ll soon be immersed in evergreen forests intersected by ice-cold distal lakes and jagged mountain peaks. This itinerary offers three perfectly paced days in the region before or after your expedition.
column37: Arrive in Ushuaia, the gateway to Antarctica at the tip of South America. Here, your Swoop guide will greet you and usher you by private transfer to your centrally located hotel. Settle in, then wander outside to soak up the crisp air and take in the spectacular views of the harbour, where the snow-capped mountain peaks tumble down to the glittering waters of the Beagle Channel.Meals: None included
column46: Today, embark on a memorable hike to a gemstone-coloured lake cradled by towering mountain peaks. After a morning pickup from your hotel, take a short drive out of the port city to the trailhead, where the route starts amid lush subantarctic forests teeming with native plants. Weave your way around peaty bogs and past intricate beaver dams, each step bringing you closer to the glimmering turquoise waters of the lagoon. Here, refuel with a well-earned picnic lunch and pause to take in the peaceful views. Scan the skies as you rest – you might catch the majestic sight of soaring condors before you make your way back along the trails and drive to Ushuaia. This evening, take some time to explore the port city's eclectic centre. Your guide can recommend the top places to sample the best of traditional Patagonian cuisine. Excursion: Hiking tour at Lake Esmeralda on a small group or private basis Meals: Breakfast at your hotel, picnic lunch en route
column60: On your final morning, stroll through the city and take in the local sights. Snap a photo at the iconic Ushuaia sign then amble along the bustling harbour, where you can watch the ships prepare for their journeys to the end of the Earth. If you have time today, speak with our destination experts about adding a day tour to the rugged peaks and ancient forests of Tierra del Fuego National Park. Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column5: Nestled at the foot of the imposing Central Andes, Chile's enigmatic capital is an eclectic mix of sleek city skyscrapers and colonial old-town charm. Get the most out of a whistlestop visit with our express itinerary, which showcases the highlights and leaves you eager to return.
column37: Descend on Santiago and take in the sweeping views of the surrounding snow-capped mountains. As you exit through the airport, your Swoop guide will greet you and usher you by private vehicle to your centrally located hotel. Depending on your flight arrival time, you'll enjoy a tour of this enticing city either this afternoon or tomorrow morning. Your guide will bring Santiago's intoxicating blend of modernity and tradition to life by showing you landmarks such as the vast Plaza de Armas – the city's colonial heart – and the grand 18th Century Metropolitan Cathedral. Amble along wide boulevards towards the historic La Moneda Palace, home to Chile's present-day government, then ascend San Cristóbal Hill by funicular or cable car. Here, you can gaze out over the sprawling Santiago cityscape set against the dramatic peaks of the Andes. Pause for a peaceful moment at the hilltop sanctuary before making your way down to the artistic neighbourhood of Bellavista.At the end of this action-packed tour, your guide will drop you back to your hotel. Make the most of their insider knowledge by asking where to find the best restaurants for an authentic Chilean meal this evening. column5: This short break covers the very best of the Chilean capital and its natural surroundings. Immerse yourself in the city’s rich history and culture, then head east to sample the nation’s finest exports at a scenic vineyard with breathtaking views of the Andes.
column37: Arrive in Santiago and be greeted at the airport by your English-speaking guide, who will whisk you to your centrally located hotel by private vehicle. After checking in, wander the surrounding neighbourhood, immersing yourself in the vibrant sights and sounds of Chile's capital. column46: This morning, your guide will pick you up from your hotel for an in-depth tour of the city. Begin at the Plaza de Armas, the colonial heart of Santiago, where you'll learn about the origins of the settlement and the collapse of Spanish rule. Next, admire the grandeur of the Metropolitan Cathedral, home to the city's archbishop, before taking in the neoclassical La Moneda Palace, the seat of government.Another must-see is San Cristóbal Hill, one of the city's most iconic landmarks. Ride the funicular or cable car to the summit for panoramic views of Santiago with the Andes rising high in the background. Pause for a peaceful moment at the hillside sanctuary before making your way down to the artsy Bellavista district. You'll have some free time for lunch ahead of a vineyard visit just outside the city. Explore the lush green estate on a guided tour and learn about the wine-making process before finishing with a delectable tasting. At the end of the day, return to your hotel for a relaxed final evening in the city. column5: Do justice to Santiago and its nearby highlights with this action-packed three-night itinerary. Immerse yourself in the city's colonial history and vibrant energy before venturing to the UNESCO-listed hillside town of Valparaíso, an enthralling blend of multicoloured buildings and street art. Finally, indulge in Chile’s world-class wines on a visit to a refined Casablanca Valley vineyard.
column37: Arrive in Chile's energetic capital, set against the spectacular backdrop of the snow-capped Andes. Your English-speaking guide will be waiting to welcome you at the airport before escorting you by private vehicle to your centrally located hotel. Once you're settled in, spend the afternoon exploring your surroundings while enjoying the warmth of the city. Stroll through the lively neighbourhood, dipping into the artisanal shops and cafes. During your earlier transfer, we recommend asking where you can find the most refreshing mote con huesillo, the locals' favourite peach-flavoured summer drink.Meals: None included
column46: After breakfast at your hotel, embark on a city tour covering the history and highlights of Santiago. Explore the city's colonial heart at the vast Plaza de Armas, admire the ornate decor of the grand 18th-century Metropolitan Cathedral, and learn about Chile's fight for democracy at the governmental La Moneda Palace. Next, take a cable car or funicular to the top of San Cristóbal Hill and enjoy the contrast between the sprawling metropolis and the sky-brushing Andes mountain range beyond. Pause for a moment of reflection at the peaceful hilltop Santuario de la Inmaculada Concepción before returning to the city and wandering through Bellavista, the centre of Chilean nightlife. Excursion: Four-hour city tour on a small group or private basisMeals: Breakfast in your hotel
column60: Today, you'll explore Chile's coastal destinations of Valparaíso and Viña del Mar, along with a charming local vineyard. After driving out of the city, travel the highway past fertile farmland and fields of vines, finally arriving at the coast in Viña del Mar. Breathe in the salty sea air at the beautiful beach and explore the lush Quinta Vergara Park.Next, head to the UNESCO World Heritage city of Valparaiso to wander labyrinthine streets punctuated by vibrant murals. Enjoy free time to stop for lunch and roam the colourful alleyways, marvelling at the street art and riding the gravity-defying funiculars.In the afternoon, head back inland to your final stop, an elegant family-run vineyard in the Casablanca Valley. column5: After your journey to Chile’s enigmatic capital, regain your energy with an adventure in the majestic Andes mountain range. This itinerary combines a satisfying city break with a breathtaking hike through winding trails and soaring peaks.
column37: After you fly into Chile's capital, your English-speaking guide will make your arrival hassle free by meeting you and transferring you straight to your hotel in the city. If you arrive in the morning, spend time getting your bearings in the afternoon. Visit the heart of Santiago at the Plaza de Armas, where history seeps out of every corner. The grand Metropolitan Cathedral, a stunning example of neoclassical design, stands here as a symbol of the country's Catholic faith. Mere steps away, the elegant Renaissance-style roof of the central post office adds to the square's timeless charm.Meals: None included
column45: Hiking in Yerba Loca Nature Sanctuary
column46: Swap city life for one of Santiago's best-kept secrets today: the Yerba Loca Nature Sanctuary in the Central Andes. This park, just over an hour's drive away, is named after the estuary found at the meeting point of two mountain chains and offers a wealth of landscapes to explore. Your hike today leads along trails ranging from moderate to challenging, past flourishing flora and intriguing fauna. Keep your eyes peeled for native wildlife like grey foxes slinking across the varied terrain and the Chilean condor circling overhead. Along the route you'll be rewarded with views of the icy La Paloma Glacier glinting in the distance. Refuel with a box lunch while admiring the pristine views of boulder-strewn valleys.After the hike, return to your hotel to freshen up before getting to know your local neighbourhood, perhaps stopping off for a creamy treat from one of the city's many artisan gelaterias. Excursion: Full day hiking tour in Yerba Loca Nature Sanctuary Meals: Breakfast in your hotel, picnic lunch on the hike

When it's time to leave, your private transfer will pick you up from your hotel and take you to the airport for your flight. Meals: Breakfast in your hotel

column5: With its multicultural influences, huge central market hall and easily accessible vineyards, Santiago is the perfect place to dive into Chile's culinary culture. Try world-class wines on a vineyard tour and learn to cook authentic local cuisine during this four-day foodie experience.
column37: Land in Chile's capital, a city with a reputation for culinary excellence, and look forward to learning about its diverse cuisine. column45: Central market, cooking class and vineyard tour
column46: Start your morning with a visit to Santiago's bustling central market, a smorgasbord of enticing Chilean produce and an insight into the country's vibrant food culture. The grand iron neoclassical roof is an icon of the city, and inside you'll find a feast for the senses. Your English-speaking guide will take you to diverse stalls offering everything from fresh fruit to locally reared meat. As you weave through the fish market, you'll pick up the key ingredients required for lunch, then head to the kitchens of a local restaurant for a hands-on cooking demonstration. Afterwards, enjoy your homemade ceviche (citrus-marinated seafood) before returning to your hotel. This afternoon, explore the flavours of the Chilean terroir with a wine tasting while looking out over the soaring Andes. You'll be picked up from your hotel and taken straight to the vineyard to tour the scenic vines and taste the exceptional wines. People-watch over a cafe con leche before wandering to the presidential palace, a place that has witnessed both peaceful protests and violent coups during the country's tumultuous history. When the time comes to travel onwards, you'll be picked up from your hotel for a private transfer to the airport in time for your flight. Meals: Breakfast in your hotel

column5: Whether you’re unwinding before or defrosting after your Antarctic adventure, indulge in a peaceful break among Chile's rolling hills. Spend three relaxed days at a vineyard estate in a renowned wine region near Santiago, soaking up the South American sun while surrounded by lush gardens.
column37: Your English-speaking Swoop guide and driver will meet you at Santiago's airport and take you to the Chilean countryside and your gorgeous vineyard base. At check-in, the charming team of hosts will help you plan your stay, offering a choice of organised or self-guided activities in the splendid grounds.Dinner is an exceptional three-course meal of traditional Chilean flavours, perfectly complemented by the estate's own wines. Meals: Afternoon tea and dinner with wine pairing at your hotel
column46: After a leisurely breakfast crafted from locally produced ingredients, explore the estate at your own pace. You could take an adrenaline-pumping bike ride, hike to a breathtaking viewpoint or enjoy a gentle horse ride through the vines. Alternatively, just kick back and relax, glass in hand, beside the pool and soak up the peace in the verdant gardens. The valleys outside Santiago are known for producing some of Chile's most delicious wines, with complex flavours heavily influenced by the area's unique landscape and weather patterns. Later today, you'll learn more about the development of the local industry as you enjoy a fascinating tour of the estate and learn about the biodynamic wine-making process. Finish the tour with a guided tasting from the vineyard's exceptional selection.Excursions: A selection of activities, as chosen during check in at the hotelMeals, Breakfast, lunch, afternoon tea and dinner with wine pairing at your hotel
column60: Enjoy a farewell breakfast – and perhaps a final wander amid the vines – before you're transferred to the airport for your onward flight.Meals: Breakfast at your hotel

column3: Sea days en route to Antarctica
column5: Over the first two days, you’ll enjoy rolling seas, cool salt breezes and maybe even a fin whale spouting up sea spray.

column5: Ideal for those seeking a compact yet action-packed trip to the White Continent. From the comfort of your purpose-built X-Bow vessel, a highly experienced expedition team will help you maximise your time exploring off the ship and encourage you to get involved with fascinating citizen science projects.
column37: Today, you will arrive in Ushuaia, Argentina – the world's southernmost city. After landing at one of the continent's most picturesque airports, you will be met and transferred to your included hotel for the night. In the evening, there will be a chance to meet your fellow travellers at the pre-cruise briefing.
column46: After breakfast, you have the morning free to explore. You might like to head onto the bustling high street to pick up some souvenirs or visit the quirky Maritime Museum for some fascinating history set within the cells of an old prison. Alternatively, consider a half-day trip to the nearby Tierra del Fuego National Park with its rugged snow-capped mountains, glistening glaciers, flower-filled meadows and sparkling waters.In the afternoon you will board your ship. Your journey begins as you navigate through the calm of the Beagle Channel, a strait in the Tierra del Fuego Archipelago. Look out for wildlife as you go – this can be a great place to spot black browed albatross bobbing on the water.
column60: Sailing south, you will cross the famed Drake Passage, a body of water that marks the intersection of the cold Antarctic with the warmer Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. The Drake Passage is known for sometimes tumultuous conditions and strong westerly winds called the Roaring Fifties.While this passage can sometimes be challenging, you can rest confidently aboard your comfortable expedition vessel, which is purpose-built with stabilisers, powerful engines and manned by a highly experienced crew. Many consider crossing the Drake to be a rite of passage for any Antarctic traveller. On this body of water, the excitement builds as Antarctic wildlife begins to come into view and the countdown is on to spot your first iceberg. Head out on deck to look for seabirds – this is the best place to spot giant petrels cruising along behind the ship. There may be the opportunity to participate in citizen science projects, such as a seabird count survey and a NASA cloud observation study. Joining you on board is an incredible expedition team of naturalist guides who will prepare you for your arrival with a fascinating programme of education lectures ranging from polar exploration history to glaciology and, of course, talks on Antarctica's spectacular wildlife.
column69: Your adventure begins in earnest as you head off the ship to explore the dramatic sub-Antarctic islands of the South Shetland chain. There are plenty of options to explore, with dramatic volcanic landscapes playing the perfect backdrop to iconic Antarctic species. During your time in Antarctica, the exact daily itinerary and activities depend on weather and ice conditions. The Captain and expedition leader will determine the route and shore landings, communicated to guests through regularly scheduled briefings.The team will also look for opportunities to run citizen science projects, such as phytoplankton collection and a Secchi disk survey. These offer an unexpected way to connect with Antarctica from a completely different perspective while collecting some excellent data for scientific research!
column77: Moving further south to the Antarctic Peninsula, here the ship will cruise past glaciers cascading off the mountains like icing. The sculptural icebergs provide a constant feast for the eyes, whether you are photographing them from the deck of the ship or the sturdy zodiac rib. Keep your eyes peeled for seals hauled out on ice floes and humpback whales blowing and fluking between huge gulps of nutritious krill. On land, the penguin rookeries are a cacophonous comedy with constant drama as these petite seabirds waddle to and from their rocky nesting sites. It can sometimes be hard to put down the camera, but it's worth taking some time to soak up all the incredible sights and smells without the distraction of looking through a lens. Between or after excursions, or if the weather is proving challenging, the ship has excellent public areas to enjoy. Enjoy the views from the warm bubbles of the outdoor Jacuzzis or relax in the sauna. Read up on wildlife you've seen that day in the calm library, then grab a drink at the bar with one of the friendly expedition guides. Each evening, there will be a recap to learn more about what you've experienced that day and a rough outline of Plan A for the following day.
column85: Bid Antarctica a fond farewell and head north back towards civilisation across the Drake Passage once more. During your time at sea the educational programme will continue, the seabirds await you out on deck, and there will also be time to reflect on your adventures and start to go through your photos.
column93: Disembark the ship this morning back in Ushuaia, which can seem quite bustling after the isolation of the White Continent. From here, you can continue your adventures or begin your return journey home.

column3: Antarctic Peninsula Fly & Sail Photo Safari
column5: A photography-focused voyage with a host of expert photographers onboard to help you sharpen your camera skills and fill your memory card with the world's most photogenic landscapes and iconic wildlife. This trip flies directly south to Antarctica, maximising your time with an extensive 7 days exploring the White Continent. Then sail back north via the Drake Passage for incredible soaring seabird shot opportunities.
column37: After touching down in this Chilean port city, you will be met and transferred alongside your fellow travellers to a comfortable downtown hotel for a complimentary night's stay.Tonight, you will join a briefing focused on the first part of your expedition: the journey to Antarctica. You will be advised of the predicted timings and logistics for your included charter flight, as this will depend on weather conditions locally and on King George Island, where your plane will land.Please keep in mind that you must arrive in Punta Arenas no later than 2 pm today, as your flight to Antarctica may be pulled forward to depart earlier if weather conditions require it.
column46: A transfer will take you to Punta Arenas airport for your charter flight to Antarctica. Your intended destination is King George Island, where you will land at one of the most remote airstrips on Earth. Your pilots need clear skies and perfect visibility for safe takeoff and landing, so keep in mind that delays could be possible.The flight will take around two hours. After you arrive on King George Island, your expedition team will guide you onto a zodiac for the short transfer across the water to your waiting ship, and the adventure begins in earnest. Keep your cameras close by as you sometimes spot your first Antarctic wildlife on the landing beach!
column60: Prepare to capture the stunning beauty of the South Shetland Islands and the northwestern side of the Antarctic Peninsula through your camera lens. From dramatic sculptural icebergs to world-class wildlife, each day will offer plenty of opportunities to capture breathtaking images.During this dedicated photography expedition, you will have the chance to learn from accomplished photography guides and esteemed special guest photographers. Look forward to joining immersive lectures and picking up professional tips. Whether you want to learn how to set up your camera or enhance composition, personalised guidance will be available both onboard and during off-ship adventures. Your highly experienced Expedition Leader and Captain will carefully design each day's itinerary, selecting the best routes and activities based on the ever-changing weather and ice conditions.Typically, up to two landings or zodiac excursions are planned per day. Wrap up warm as you board one of the sturdy zodiacs, camera in hand, for close-ups of towering cliffs and grounded icebergs. Keep your lens poised for the blow of a humpback whale or the sight of seals lounging on ice floes as you cruise through pristine waters. The zodiacs will also shuttle you to shore, where you can capture the comical shuffle of penguins as they waddle along their well-worn “highways”.On land, you could wander along ice-strewn beaches while framing shots of glistening glaciers or hike to panoramic viewpoints that offer amazing compositions of the vast polar landscape below. As the voyage continues, you may cruise by ship through slender straits, snapping the bold blues and stark whites of the ice. Or linger in spectacular bays, where the ship becomes the perfect observation spot for photographing whales feasting in the krill-rich sea. While filling your memory card is the main purpose of this itinerary, there will also be plenty of times to put the camera down (and we do encourage you to do so every now and again to ensure you're not just experiencing Antarctica through the viewfinder). Your expedition guides will look for an opportunity to organise a polar plunge, where you can take an exhilarating dip in icy Antarctic waters. Alternatively, you may simply want to steal peaceful moments here and there to soak up the spectacular White Continent while listening out for the thunderous roar of calving glaciers in the distance.
column68: Sail back across the Drake Passage
column69: If conditions allow, there might be a chance for one final landing this morning on the South Shetland Islands before your ship turns back towards South America via the epic Drake Passage. The photography-focused educational programme will continue during these two days, bringing even more depth to your Antarctic experience. When you're not acquiring new knowledge, photograph the grand beauty of the Southern Ocean from the ship's spacious deck. Snap the enormous wingspan of the beautiful albatross gliding past the ship and catch the glittering waves through your lens. Test your reaction time and shutter speed against the petite cape petrels with their photogenic black and white feather patterns.  As your vessel nears the tip of South America, your Captain may attempt a distant sail-by of notorious Cape Horn, weather and time allowing.These few days at sea also provide the chance to sort through your photos – and reminisce over your recent memories – before you arrive back in civilisation.
column77: Having sailed back up the Beagle Channel, the ship will dock in Ushuaia this morning, ready for you to disembark one final time after breakfast. Bid farewell to your expedition team and the professional onboard photographers as you continue your journey around South America or towards home. We recommend booking any onward flights after midday today to allow a buffer for delays while returning from Antarctica.
column85: NULL

column3: Epic Explorer: Falklands, South Georgia & the Antarctic Circle
column5: An action-packed adventure covering many of the most spectacular must-see locations found in the southern polar region. Explore the jaw-dropping wildlife of the Falklands and South Georgia before spending an impressive 7 days in the White Continent, where you’ll also cross the Antarctic Circle. Optional additional activities available include camping, kayaking, snowshoeing and citizen science projects.
column37: After landing at Ushuaia's airport, you will be met and transferred to your comfortable hotel for a complimentary pre-cruise night. You then have time to relax or explore before attending an evening briefing. Here, you will have the opportunity to meet your fellow travellers and ask any questions regarding the logistics for tomorrow.
column46: You have the morning free to spend as you wish. You may prefer to relax at the hotel, head into the town centre to visit the quirky Maritime Museum or take an optional half-day tour of Tierra del Fuego National Park (additional cost, book in advance). This afternoon, you will be taken from the hotel to the port to embark on your expedition ship, where the onboard team will welcome you and help you settle in. After a safety briefing, the ship will drop its lines and leave Ushuaia. As you sail down the Beagle Channel, keep an eye out for black-browed albatross and petrels, as well as sea lions and perhaps even the odd Magellanic penguin. In the evening, there'll be a Captain's welcome dinner and the adventure truly begins!
column59: At sea en route to the Falkland Islands
column60: You will be at sea today, making your way towards the Falkland Islands. As you sail, the expedition team will give important briefings on environmental regulations and expedition safety. The education programme will also begin, with the onboard experts sharing fascinating talks on the wildlife, history and geology of the areas you will explore during the course of your adventure. In between these sessions, get out on deck to look for seabirds gliding past the ship – this can be a great time to photograph albatross and petrels on the wing.
column69: The Falklands are a ruggedly beautiful and windy archipelago and a wildlife lover's dream. The 700+ islands are home to the largest black-browed albatross colony in the world as well as five species of breeding penguin. Keen birders will have their binoculars constantly in action, looking out for endemic species such as the Falkland steamer duck and Cobb's wren, along with kelp gulls, dolphin gulls, black-crowned night herons, red-backed hawks, peregrine falcons and numerous goose species. Weather permitting, the ship may head to Saunders Island, the second-largest island in the Falklands. Or perhaps sail to The Neck, a narrow peninsula with sandy beaches and cliffs where elegant black-browed albatross nest. Wherever you explore, the white-sand beaches and lush grasses with grazing livestock make for a slightly baffling juxtaposition with the waddling penguins. During your time in the Falklands, the ship will also attempt to call in at the gusty port of Stanley. This quaint town is the main hub of the islands, with shops, pubs and an excellent small museum.
column76: At sea en route to South Georgia
column77: Heading further southeast towards South Georgia, you will move through the wild waters of the Southern Ocean and cross the Antarctic Convergence, where water temperatures drop. Spend time out on deck watching the seabirds that pass the ship. From the huge wingspan of the wandering albatross to the petite Wilson's storm petrel, there is always something to look out for. The expedition team will help you conduct bird counts for ongoing citizen science data collection projects. As you sail, you may also spot cetaceans – so do keep an eye out for their distinctive blows. The educational programme will continue, with lectures preparing you for the jaw-dropping wildlife and epic tales of polar explorers who have passed through South Georgia.
column85: Exploring South Georgia can feel like you have fallen into a live-action wildlife documentary. The island is sometimes hailed as the ‘Serengeti of the Southern Ocean' as its densely packed shorelines burst with king penguins, elephant seals and fur seals. Sometimes, the beaches are so full of wildlife that it's impossible to get ashore. Other times, your expedition team will mark the way to the edge of enormous king penguin rookeries, where the wind carries a cacophony of trills and the biggest challenge is deciding which way to focus your attention.The island itself is geologically beautiful, with glaciers pouring down the jagged mountains providing the perfect backdrop for your wildlife photography. The human history is also fascinating, and sometimes emotionally challenging, with the now-defunct whaling industry still clearly evidenced by crumbling whaling stations such as Grytviken. Here, fans of legendary polar explorer Ernest Shackleton will be able to visit the graveyard to toast the Boss himself with a dram of whisky. The exact locations visited will be planned by your Expedition Leader and Captain based around the most favourable weather conditions.
column92: At sea en route to Antarctica
column93: Heading southwest from South Georgia, you'll spend time crossing the Scotia Sea as you sail towards Antarctica.The educational programming will continue, but do spend time out on deck as you will spot icebergs heralding your arrival in Antarctic waters.
column102: Exploring the South Shetlands & Antarctic Peninsula
column103: The White Continent is simply breathtaking, and every moment is a feast for the eyes (and camera lens!). Your expedition leader will plan an action-packed itinerary based on the best weather and ice conditions. They will aim to have you off the ship twice a day exploring Antarctica's spectacular landscapes and wildlife. You may be heading ashore to enjoy the drama of a gentoo penguin rookery or on a hike through snow to enjoy glorious views out across ice-laden mountains. Alternatively, you may be out zodiac cruising, enjoying the incredible textures, shapes and hues of icebergs. As you explore, be on the lookout for seals hauled out for a rest or whales gorging on krill. For those who have signed up for optional activities, the team will look for the right conditions to offer kayaking, camping and snowshoeing. They'll also run citizen science zodiacs where guests can get hands-on by helping to collect samples for research projects (sign up on board).
column110: Heading south towards the Antarctic Circle
column111: The Captain will sail south during your time in Antarctica, exploring along the way. Their aim is to bring the ship to the latitude of 66°33'S. Here, a toast and celebration await as you cross the Antarctic Circle. Please note that the exact timings and routing will be based on the weather and ice conditions.
column118: Heading north towards the South Shetland Islands
column119: Your exploration will continue as you head north once again. Spend any free time out on deck looking for the blow of humpback whales, or the splash of penguins porpoising through the water. Enjoy watching the shape of an iceberg change as you sail past and discover new angles.
column126: At sea crossing the Drake Passage northbound
column127: Bid Antarctica farewell as you make the journey north across the infamous Drake Passage. There will be time to sort through your photos as you sail, but the education programme is still in full force, with great opportunities to learn more about the history, wildlife and geology of the incredible locations you have explored. As you approach civilisation, you will celebrate the conclusion of your adventure with a special slideshow, guest photo contest and a final meal together.
column136: The hustle and bustle of civilisation can feel a little jarring after weeks exploring some of the most remote locations on the planet. It's time to say goodbye to your expedition team and crew as you disembark the ship in Ushuaia. You can then fly back north to Buenos Aires this afternoon or continue your onward adventure.
